title: Find Out Which Of The 10 US National Parks Matches Your Vibe In Seconds With Our New Quiz
excerpt: The United States is home to 63 incredible national parks , each a treasure trove of stunning landscapes, unique wildlife, and unforgettable adventures. From the majestic peaks of the Rockies to the otherworldly deserts of California, the options are almost endless.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The United States is home to 63 incredible national parks, each a treasure trove of stunning landscapes, unique wildlife, and unforgettable adventures. From the majestic peaks of the Rockies to the otherworldly deserts of California, the options are almost endless.

Every year, millions of travelers flock to these natural wonders, making them some of the most sought-after destinations in the country.

But with so many epic choices, travelers often face a tough question: which park is the right one for my trip? That’s where we at Travel Off Path come in.

We created a brand-new interactive quiz designed to cut through the noise and match you with your perfect national park in under 30 seconds.

America's 10 Most Popular Parks

To give you an idea of the incredible options available, here are the 10 most-visited national parks in the United States, currently drawing the largest crowds with their world-renowned scenery.

  • Great Smoky Mountains National Park
  • Grand Canyon National Park
  • Zion National Park
  • Yellowstone National Park
  • Rocky Mountain National Park
  • Yosemite National Park
  • Acadia National Park
  • Grand Teton National Park
  • Joshua Tree National Park
  • Olympic National Park

But Which One Is Right For You?

Seeing the list of the most popular parks is a great starting point, but it doesn't answer the most important question: which one fits your unique travel style?

A park's popularity doesn't guarantee it's your perfect match. The last thing you want is to book a vacation centered on strenuous activity when you were really hoping for a more relaxed vibe.

Choosing a park that aligns with your interests is the secret to an amazing trip. In a year where some parks are seeing absolutely massive crowds, knowing your priorities can help you find a better experience.

Do you want to see iconic wildlife like bears and bison, or are you hoping to find a unique slice of solitude under a blanket of stars? Answering these questions first is key.

What kind of scenery calls to you?

How do you want to spend your day?

And your #1 priority is…?

title: Americans Now Need To Get A Digital Entry Permit When Traveling To This Trendy Asian Country
excerpt: It seems the era of low-bureaucracy travel is officially over. After the United Kingdom rolled out its ETA back in January, affecting all Americans, and Saint Kitts and Nevis followed suit in recent weeks, the next country to introduce a digital entry permit is the laid-back L…
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
It seems the era of low-bureaucracy travel is officially over. After the United Kingdom rolled out its ETA back in January, affecting all Americans, and Saint Kitts and Nevis followed suit in recent weeks, the next country to introduce a digital entry permit is the laid-back Laos:

One of the most welcoming nations in Southeast Asia, the ‘Land of a Million Elephants' will be adding a mandatory step for all Americans, and any foreign traveler who's visiting for tourism.

In addition to applying for the e-Visa or a Visa On Arrival, they will now need to complete the Lao Digital Immigration Form (LDIF), an arrival card that must be presented to border officers upon arrival.

New Digital Arrival Card Required For Travelers Arriving in Laos

According to the official statement put out by the Department of Immigration of Laos, ‘all foreign nationals and stateless people' entering Laos are now required to complete a digital arrival card at the agency's official website.

This applies not only to when they enter the country, but also when they leave, and in both instances, it must be done at least three days before the intended date of arrival and departure.

It's unclear at this point whether you can be barred from boarding your flight, right at your point of departure, for failing to produce a completed arrival card.

However, it has been suggested that non-compliant travelers will not be allowed into the country until they've finalized the procedure.

Checklist For Going To Laos In 2025

This has been the new guideline as of September 1, 2025.

In sum, as a U.S. passport holder, you need to ensure you have all the following documentation when traveling to Laos:

  • A valid passportwith at leasttwofull blank pages for entry and exit stamps
  • An e-Visa, or a means of purchasing a Visa On Arrival, when landing in the country
  • The completed Arrival Card
  • Upon exit, a completed Departure Card

What Information Is Required By Laos Authorities?

As far as forms go, the Arrival/Exit Cards are exceedingly detailed, with the following information being required:

  • Airport or port of entry
  • Arrival date
  • Full name
  • Gender
  • Date of birth
  • Place of birth
  • Nationality
  • Occupation
  • Country of origin
  • Phone number
  • Passport number
  • Date of issue
  • Expiry date
  • Country of issue
  • Copy of passport information page
  • A selfie of the applicant holding their passport open on the information (photo) page

  • Options include Diplomatic or Official Visit, Business, Tourism, or Transit
  • Air, car, or bus
  • Number of means of transportation
  • Country of origin
  • Inform them whether you're traveling with a group or not
  • Type of visa requested
  • Visa number (if an e-Visa or other form of visa has already been obtained in advance)
  • Date and place of visa issuance (if applicable)
  • A photo of the valid visa (if applicable)

  • Name of accommodation or hotel
  • Province
  • District
  • Municipality
  • Intended check-in date
  • Intended check-out date

Were it not for the absence of financial details, we wouldn't blame you for thinking this lengthy questionnaire looks, well, like a full visa application.

The good part is that it is completely free (as of now), and once submitted and approved, travelers will be issued a QR code that must then be scanned at the border gate upon arrival in Laos.

Less Wait At Laotian Airports

Currently, only 4 airports are impacted, those being Wattay International, which serves the national capital, Vientiane, Luang Prabang International, the main gateway to the namesake, culture-loaded province, Pakse (in the Champasak Province), and the First Lao-Thai Friendship Bridge.

The latter is a land crossing from Nong Khai, in Thailand, to Vientiane.

The goal is to introduce the new measure at all of Laos' international entry points, but full coverage is only likely to be achieved in 2026.

As the Government has put it, this new system will reduce waiting lines upon arrival, as it will do away with physical forms and unnecessary queuing, and it will also make the job of border officers a lot easier, as much of the information they require from travelers will be transmitted beforehand.

title: Serpent Carriers by K.A. Teryna, translated by Alex Shvartsman
excerpt: 14500 words, novelette
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
14500 words, novelette

Old people are of little use, but on occasion, they know stories and are skilled at telling them. Jorge, an old man with a face wrinkled and cracked like last year’s berry, kept his stories to himself.

As she looked at him from afar, Rioja imagined how stories accumulated within Jorge, how they roiled and mixed and quarreled. There was probably an ever-present and tremendous tumult within his head. Jorge spent his nights with the shepherds: He sat hunched over, just outside the range of the light cast by the fire, and smoked his pipe in silence. He listened to others but told no stories of his own. The shepherds didn’t like Jorge but didn’t dare chase him away. When Jorge approached the fire, the shepherds exchanged glances and frowned but still offered him a helping of broth in a rusty mug. You never knew when old people might be ready to die, and when they’re ready, what their last word will be, and whether that last word will be about you. And whether it will be a Word.

It had been a long time since Words existed on Ilion; only their descriptions were passed from father to son, like a grandfather’s snuffbox in a city devoid of tobacco. But the memory of Words continued to instill a vague unease. People recalling them would glance disapprovingly at the sky with its two moons; the sky where Words used to come from, along with Meteor Birds and news of the greater world. Over many quiet years, Words became a legend, which only children were foolhardy enough to repeat since their souls weren’t yet encased in the crust of quietude.

Fall had always been the time to gather supplies. To store extra quantities of berries, stories, and warmth. Even Rioja’s decrepit yak, who disliked cities and well-trodden shepherd paths, sought out the company of his kind in the fall.

All the cities Rioja and her yak encountered on their journey were alike: the old world waned in the embrace of Ilion’s bountiful nature; Archaic and Benzel plants covered the walls of houses; yaks wandered the wide boulevards and spacious squares; and unflappable shepherds smoked in the shadows of crumbling walls.

Rioja would leave her yak to graze on the outskirts and wander in places where it couldn’t pass: the labyrinths of narrow streets in the heart of the city. She wasn’t looking for anything specific but tried to find purpose in what she saw. At times, she thought that purpose was hidden in the rays of light broken by the city skyline, odd and—for some reason—very cheerful. She’d walk in the shade of the old streets, turn the corner, and encounter perfection. She’d suddenly realize those who came before had walked these streets in the same way for hundreds and thousands of years.

The farm towers rose in the east, impressive even at a great distance. Shepherds disliked the eastern wind and were suspicious of any person from the east. Rioja came from the west and could’ve told them that the farms were the same everywhere, that western farms were no better than the eastern ones. But she remained silent and hid her wrists and palms within long sleeves.

The fall in southern Ilion was soft and golden. As she gazed at the carpet of leaves, Rioja thought that perhaps they held purpose. Or perhaps it was in the crunching sound, loud enough to spread across empty streets, when she waded knee-deep in those leaves. At times, she saw the old Jorge in the distance—snoozing on the bench under the broken clock in front of the train station building.

She had explored the entire city, and it was time to move on, but Rioja hesitated. She was curious about Jorge. She wanted a closer look. Either sensing her curiosity or obeying the will of the fall, Jorge became restless and perturbed. It seemed as though he was not a single person but two or three or a whole dozen. At times, he didn’t seem like a person at all.

title: Bits and Pieces on This Floor by Eric Del Carlo
excerpt: 4050 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
4050 words, short story

Terraforming colossi—the sort our corp manufactured, at any rate—were made to seem permanent, reassuringly stolid, as if monuments. This promoted confidence in the seeder population, who needed, above all else, to believe in the planet to which they had come.

Nevertheless, our teams dismantled the gigantic, gleaming hourglass-shaped artifacts in a matter of hours. This meant the alien air was no longer being treated, and the world, from which useful resources had been extracted for a generation and a half, would lose its breathable atmosphere within nine days.

I was not among the dismantling crews. I hadn’t the artisan skills. My place was with the small army tasked with seeing that every seeder was off this world before the deadline. I did possess a bona fide rank; however, I’d risen that far within the corp echelons, at least.

This meant I had an underling. She was young, or young to me. And probably taut and tawny as well, but I really didn’t bother to notice. Her name was Koç. We stood together at the foot of the main drag in the only city, next to a Galactic Collective evac ship. Commercial craft had come and gone, and if you were a responsible person, you would have booked passage on one of them; meaning: you could depart in an orderly fashion, with any and all personal goods you desired to take, also with some dignity. Ninety-nine point two percent of the population had done just that.

What was left, we were herding onto this relief boat.

“İsa Mesih,” Koç muttered in whatever old Earth language she was affecting. I didn’t know the translation, but her contempt came through clearly. It was for the straggly, raggedy line of seeders coming down the street. Actually, “seeders” was overstating it in their case; these were the dregs. These were the irresponsible. Hard luck types, all of them, who’d likely contributed next to nothing to the ongoing resources-extraction project on this world. But our corp had opened the planet, and the great benevolent GC said we had to withdraw every last person from the face of it before they asphyxiated in the reverting atmospheric conditions.

We were in our neat corp uniforms. This made Koç and me an even better target for the stragglers’ outrage than the Galactic Collective ship personnel, who were stripping bags and cases out of their hands and heaving them onto heaps by the ramp. “No personal effects,” was the repeated refrain. The GC’s big-heartedness was real, but it was not absolute.

“Why’re you taking my stuff?”

“Corporate monsters!”

“I hope you choke!”

I paid more attention to my underling, making sure she didn’t react. She sneered, silently. Even that was more than I liked, but I couldn’t fault her. One of the latecomers came stumping along, wearing one patched engineering boot and one fuzzy orange slipper, the picture of dishevelment and emotional chaos. “Bang” was the name of the cheap drug most often found on these dig-and-ditch worlds, and this individual looked like a habitual user. He looked ravaged by it, in fact.

“M . . . m . . . my mother’s buried here,” he said to us in surprisingly lucid tones, with bomb-blasted eyes. There was a rock near his orange foot. He kept looking down at it, up at us. But he wasn’t so banged that he didn’t recognize that we wore sidearms.

Later, when the queue stopped coming and we were walking slowly up the street, Koç said to me, “Don’t they understand this whole operation had a time limit? And—that one’s mother was buried. What the hell barbaric practice is—”

I cut in with some supervisorial wisdom. “Seeders dig. And they get dug in. It’s very difficult to avoid. They have memories here, a culture, even.” I pointed to a building’s weathered plaster front, a sign affixed to it. “Years from now—decades—somebody will still be telling about the good times they had at Pedro’s, the drinks, the pool games, the funny incidents. It will be lore. And we’ve taken all that away from them.”

title: A Land Called Folly by Amal Singh
excerpt: 3660 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
3660 words, short story

Listen.

You call them Saur-Antriksham in the old tongue, Gevesham in the new. You remember all the times the cold metal fell away from your feet as your body felt light, gravity rejecting you, then embracing you, slowly, once again. You remember the white halo around space fleets as they disappeared into the vast nothing, appearing inside another Saur-Antriksham, another Gevesham, some lightyears away, within an eye blink or two. When you were a child, you dreamed of becoming a Fleet Commander, if only to experience that split-second travel, where your insides got churned, mixed, recopied, reinvigorated, alive on the other side.

You always thought it was a copy that emerged on the other side, even when every evidence suggested it wasn’t the case. When your grandfather, Fleet Commander Sunil Sharma, returned from Karom-Karra, you refused to touch his feet because you thought he was a copy of a copy, not the smiling, slightly bucktoothed grandpa who had left Dhara, but a facsimile who didn’t remember his grandchild’s nickname.

“How are you, Kuku?” he said. You were called Kiki. The misplaced vowel sound was annoying to you because Kuku was a cartoon character you hated. You ran away from your grandfather in annoyance, stumbled on a chipped edge of the cement floor, and fell face-first on the ground. You remember your mother pulling you up, dusting you off, wiping your face. “Why are you behaving childishly, Kiki?” And you’d think something to the tune of, “But I am a child,” but say nothing.

“Big boys don’t do that. Now, apologize to your Dadaji!” she said, but you didn’t listen. You didn’t apologize. You grew up to more calls for apology, for other things that weren’t your mistakes, but you didn’t apologize, and then you grew up more, until your shoulders dropped from all the burden of non-apologies.

Your ears are numb to the groaning sounds of Saur-Antriksham, Gevesham, when you were made to see off your grandfather one last time. It’s the one above your home planet, Dhara, its faint silver outline visible from the base of the Himalayas, the bureaucratic anomaly, the one that shouldn’t even exist because it was made hastily because the powers that be were in a race, the one that is made with spare parts of long-forgotten railway stations, airports ripped apart, their still sturdy aluminum used cheaply to build an edifice that would stand the test of time, sending your people to other homes.

Ants crawl on your irises because this time you can’t bear to see the halo engulf the spacecraft, your ears ringing with their anticipatory final tremor, a tremor soaked by the aluminum benches welded into the bone white surface of the waiting area, where final goodbyes are done. Once the spacecraft is gone, there’s only the vast deep purpleness of space.

Then, there are the homeless, who are given bleak gray cabins inside the Gevesham, given gruel to eat, their only entertainment watching these spacecraft come and go every couple of hours or so. More than the voice that announces space traffic, it’s the homeless that know what goes on on other planets. They gossip among themselves, and if you listen closely, they will tell you.

That planet is full of red barbarians that hollow your insides out and wear your skin. The ones returning are the barbarians, not the humans that were sent!

They say they’re sowing the seeds of life there. But they’re just escaping this hellhole.

There’s a McDonald’s in Karom-Karra. They are using alien meat.

You were never allowed to talk to them. Why were they here and not on the actual planet that was their home, Dhara? You wanted big answers to easy questions. But before you could approach one of the homeless, you were pulled away by your parents.

“They are devaputras, you should never look in their direction, lest you want to get burned to cinders.”

“But why are they there?”

“Don’t ask unnecessary questions!”

title: Hunter Harvester by Bam Bruin
excerpt: 3670 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
3670 words, short story

Bunch, you’ll be able to find most of this in the official reports. Considering what we learned that day, there will be plenty of them. But let me tell you what happened, how it was for me. You, of all people, should want to hear it.

It was morning still, when the doctor told me about you, just before she got called away for some minor emergency. The examination room suddenly felt too small. I began to breathe hard and felt my heart beat fast. I quickly zipped up my coveralls and peeked out to see where the doctor had gone, then moved fast in the other direction. Keeping quiet, I exited the medical dome. Outside, I leaned against the next dome and for a moment tasted only Baber’s sweet air—and whatever was coming up my throat.

I panicked, wanted to keep moving. When I saw a large rover start up across the town square, I got out in front and waved it down. The rover duly stopped, swaying a little on its six giant wheels, and Revazova peeked out the window. She frowned as I climbed the ladder but held the door open for me.

“Where to?” I asked, trying to smile as I drew level with her.

“Cabbage hunt,” she answered with a shrug.

“I’ll lend a hand,” I said, getting in. But I froze when I saw the rover’s one other passenger. Hwang. Always so certain, always ready to make the right decision. She looked at me as I took a seat, then turned away with a short nod and set the rover back on its way with a few taps on its control screen.

“Every chance you’ll get to find a Folder, huh?” Revazova shook her head at me. “Anyone else, and I’d wonder if they’d gone crazy. Volunteering for a hunt . . . ”

“Doesn’t calling it a hunt make it more exciting?” I jabbed back. Still, I was grateful for Revazova’s habit of making quick assumptions, for a change. It saved me the effort of having to explain myself. She wasn’t stupid, of course: I had been tagging along with about every vehicle that might come near the forests. Back when we arrived, and Baber was still full of unknowns, our landing site in the middle of a wide-open area made sense. But as a biologist, and the only one specialized in behavior instead of biochemistry, I needed to be in the forests. That’s where we found the Folders.

Less exciting but no less important, the forests are also where the cabbages grow. We were far behind schedule in growing any Earth crop in meaningful amounts. Miraculously, the cabbages cover our every nutritional need—and they didn’t even taste half bad. We’d been surviving on them since our stores ran low. Their only downside appeared to be the long trips back and forth to the forests to harvest them.

“Thank you for helping out,” Hwang said when she was done plotting the rover’s route. She turned her seat around, and if her gaze normally made me feel like I let her down, this morning it made me burn with guilt. Hwang was currently Leader, a natural in that role, and had held the position multiple times before. My throat felt pinched, and I replied with only a grunt as I opened a window.

The rover had left the domes behind and picked up speed on the rolling hills. I stuck out my hand to feel the breeze that rippled through the blue and yellow flyflower fields. The silver-green sun was already warm, glittering in the scattered ponds. When the rover slowed down to crest a hill, I could see a single flyflower reach out above the others, its blue petals fluttering to reveal a furry, segmented body inside. Soon it tore itself loose from trailing, withered roots and found its stride. The newly born flowerfly soared away on the breeze, and for a moment, I forgot everything but the sheer joy of being on this strange planet full of wonderful life.

title: Wilderness Resurrection and Compromise by Priya Sridhar
excerpt: Non-Fiction
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Non-Fiction

Humans have a gift for wiping out predatory species. Fear and misunderstanding sometimes motivate these decisions, and by the time we realize our mistake, it’s often too late. Those with power in their hands often refuse to admit they did something wrong, and the United States is still a primary sponsor of trophy hunting and hunting animals for sport. That often means we must work around the decision-makers, negotiate, put in safeguards, or constantly remind the perpetrators of their inhumane destruction.

We also don’t have a definite answer on one important issue: reintroducing species to their natural environments after reinvigorating dwindling or very small numbers. Clashes with existing species and humans and new ones are always emerging, like a species of the cloud tiger cat in South America. Though they are shy and avoid humans, habitat destruction and interested trophy hunters threaten them. The same goes for many other species we haven’t identified yet. And what about our desire to bring back those that have gone extinct?

A Clone Cacophony

In April 2025, a company named Colossal Biosciences claimed to bring back the dire wolf, a species that died out ten thousand years ago. New Scientist has confirmed this is not the case; the dire wolf and gray wolf last had a common ancestor six million years ago. In fact, “the two species share 99.5 percent of their DNA. Since the gray wolf genome is around 2.4 billion base pairs” (Le Page 2025), that means 120 million base pairs are different between the two species. To create the three cubs, Colossal Biosciences made twenty gene edits. Editing gray wolf DNA to “resurrect” the dire wolf would require far more edits and need accurate predictions for any potential mutation.

The actual work they’re doing to help species restoration would help endangered ones; per Yahoo News, “Colossal scientists hope to use what they’ve learned to help the endangered red ‘ghost’ wolf, which has a very limited gene pool remaining” (Hayes 2025). Using gene editing to increase diversity within a species and reduce the long-term hazards of inbreeding would assist many slow-breeding animals.

There is also the big question: what do we do when the extinction is reversed? How do we handle backlash from interested decision-makers like farmers, ranchers, poachers, trophy hunters, influencers, and loggers?

The first solution that comes to mind is creating zoos and preserves with controlled environments. Science fiction, however, has told us that humans are not very good at zoology with extinct species. Our cinematic counterparts never listen to the experts.

“Welcome to Jurassic Park!”

Both the novel and film versions of Michael Crichton’s classic show the consequences of not managing a properly controlled environment for extinct species. In both cases, Dr. John Hammond tries to create a dinosaur zoo where the herbivores would “wow” the target demographic, and the carnivores would scare them. Certain species of dinosaur are much larger or smarter than the humans viewing them. Large ones can trample the guests, while the smaller and sometimes smarter carnivores can trap anyone unlucky enough to end up in their sights. Dr. Hammond, Dr. Henry Wu, and head engineer, Ray Arnold, all believe electric fences and a single game warden, Robert Muldoon, will keep the park under control.

Enter one of our protagonists, Dr. Ian Malcolm. The book version of Malcolm uses chaos theory to explain that the park has too many unknown variables to guarantee guest safety. In the movie, Malcolm says that Hammond hasn’t thought through all the worst-case possibilities when featuring a park with extinct dinosaurs and scoffs that the Jurassic Park managers are wielding genetic force “like your dad’s gun” (Spielberg 1993). This sentiment is expertly demonstrated in the infamous steer feeding scene, and though our Drs. Malcolm, Sattler, and Grant don’t actually see the dinosaurs, they see what remains of the live lunch that was lowered into the enclosure.

title: Who Owns A Story: An Interview with Allison King by Arley Sorg
excerpt: Interview
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Interview

Allison King grew up in New Jersey and spent many summers in Taiwan, where she’d visit her cousin. “At first, we role-played some of our favorite stories, such as playing the hares in Redwall. Then we started writing our own stories and fan fiction.” Over the years, they continued to send each other stories, which was very likely the seed of a career in writing.

King went to Swarthmore, which was forty-five minutes from her hometown. She majored in engineering, focusing on computer engineering, thinking she’d work in hardware. But it turned out that the English classes were the ones she enjoyed the most. “There was a great Tolkien & Pullman class, and one on Asian American literature that really had a great impact on me. I took my first creative writing workshop my senior year. The engineering requirements made it so there were few opportunities to take other classes, but I really treasure the ones I did take.”

After college, Allison King wanted to “venture out a bit . . . my first job was kind of an in-between hardware and software role at MIT Lincoln Laboratory.” She developed more software skills and eventually transitioned to focusing primarily on software. She then worked at Cortico, a nonprofit based out of the MIT Media Lab whose mission Allison described as “amplifying underheard voices via deep community conversations.” Working at Cortico was the first job that merged her interest in technology with her love of storytelling, a job she held longer than any other. She went from Cortico to Ethyca, a data privacy start-up, “where my claim to fame is having worked on the cookie banner that pops up on The New York Times’ website in the EU. Although I love the idea of data privacy, I didn’t enjoy the for-profit start-up life.” Next, she worked at another nonprofit, one that also came out of the MIT Media Lab: Knowledge Futures.

King’s fiction career kicked off with “Eden,” published in Flash Fiction Magazine (July 2019). “Breath of the Dragon King” was published in the October 2021 issue of Fantasy Magazine. Her Fantasy piece received glowing reviews and was reprinted in Paula Guran’s anthology The Year’s Best Fantasy: Volume One (Pyr, 2022).Micro-fiction “And Again, We Try” appeared in If There’s Anyone Left (April 2022); and then “The Many Taste Grooves of the Chang Family” landed in Diabolical Plots (May 2022)—to a bevy of glowing reviews. Her Diabolical story was even picked up for LeVar Burton Reads and made it onto the Locus Recommended Reading List. “Tina Yu and the Karaoke Time Machine” appeared in the January 2023 issue of khōréō.

Allison King’s cousin is Lin King, who is also a writer and a translator. “We are still very close, and it’s fun to have ended up both as professional writers. And a random fun fact is that an anagram of my name is ‘Also Lin King,’ which our parents did not intend!”

Allison King lives in Cambridge, “mostly because many of my friends have ended up here too, and there are amazing bookstores here.” On her site, she describes herself as “a fullstack engineer building open-source tools to make information useful” whose work in technology “has ranged from semiconductors to platforms for community conversations to data privacy.” When she’s not working or writing, she is hanging out with her cat and dog, or drinking tea; in fact, she’s planning to work a few hours a week in a local tea shop. “My current long-term goal is to be able to do a pull-up.”

King’s debut novel is The Phoenix Pencil Company, where “a hidden and nearly forgotten magic—of Reforging pencils, bringing the memories they contain back to life—holds the power to transform a young woman’s relationship with her grandmother, and to mend long-lost connections across time and space.” The book was released last month by HarperCollins imprint William Morrow.

Who do you see as your “writing heroes”—folks who inspired you or otherwise meant something to you; or, what are the works that you see as important to you, and why?

title: Missing Helen by Tia Tashiro
excerpt: 5830 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
5830 words, short story

When Mark told you he was marrying your clone, you said “congratulations” on autopilot, because that’s what you say when your friend tells you they’re getting married, and you had promised to stay friendly after the divorce.

You studied his face, his fingers crimping the pleats of his dress pants. That judgmental twist crept onto the corner of your lips without you quite realizing it. Mark—poor Mark—was out of place in the living room you’d once shared. Sunk down into the ratty secondhand sofa you must’ve bought when, in a fit of pettiness, you’d thrown out the old one. Sitting there in his suit, his salt-and-pepper hair slicked back in the dashing way you used to like, he could tell you thought him as awkward as a child in grown-up clothes.

“It’s all right if you need some time to process it,” Mark said.

You leaned lazily back against the counter, giving him a terse smile. You were every inch Helen of Troy, his old nickname for you—imperious, lovely, beating your shock into submission. “That’s okay,” you said—then, lamely, “I thought you were going to ask for a kidney or something.”

He saw the quick flicker of your gaze toward the end of a Band-aid sticking out from under his sleeve, covering up the tail of his reef shark tattoo. A crack in your uncaring façade. A glimpse into your psyche. Your matching one undulated up the inside of your wrist, an organic curve of stippled ink. You’d gotten them on your fifth anniversary, when he’d surprised you with a trip to Australia in an attempt to revitalize the sagging skin of your marriage.

You’d seen the shark that inspired the tats while on a guided scuba dive over a once-bleached expanse of the Great Barrier Reef. Advancements in marine regenerative tech had repopulated enough polyps that the coral was making a comeback, blooms of red and orange branching up through the water. Fish wove in and out of the recuperating ecosystem.

You both pushed a burst of air through your regulators when you saw the shark, its gray back rippling with sunlight as it swept through the ocean. You told him the shark was proof of concept that, as a species, you hadn’t fucked it up as royally as you’d thought.

What a memory: The shark. The fish. The reef.

“Just like our marriage,” he’d joked later in the cabana. “Coming back to life.”

That’s the kind of story you’d think his fiancée might be jealous of, though you wouldn’t know he’s already told her. Already bared your shared stories, your flaws, all to assuage her lingering doubts. He’s an honest man; honesty is attractive. You must’ve known that, once.

The Band-aid is a reminder. He already has an appointment to remove the tattoo next week, long before the wedding.

You sold the rights for your cloning the week after you were legally emancipated, freshly sixteen and flat broke. Just like you had done your research for the emancipation—found the forms, collected the evidence of neglect and verbal abuse, submitted the appropriate documentation to the courts—you had already identified the best site to put your genetic material up for sale.

It was called Angels in Advance. Profiles of people marched past, all ages—flattering pictures. (Some were tagged with yellow warning banners that the site generated when it suspected AI airbrushing, its detection software picking up signs of augmentation imperceptible to the human eye. To avoid liability for misleading images, Angels in Advance made it clear its visitors were responsible for verifying the accuracy of posted pictures before completing a purchase.) The profiles were accompanied by college admissions test scores, zodiac signs, favorite breakfast foods—whatever miscellanea people thought would get their picture chosen by discerning (and, hopefully, rich) future parents.

There used to be sites like AIA for buying eggs or sperm. This egg comes from a basketball star; this sperm is sourced from a Pulitzer finalist. Those sites were still popular with some—but they were also a risk. You didn’t know exactly what you were getting. The clay could fire in any form.

title: The Walled Garden by Fiona Moore
excerpt: 6530 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
6530 words, short story

Not long after the local billionaire was shot by his own robots in the Georgian manor house he’d refitted as his survival bunker, Morag packed up her rucksack, left her parents’ farm, and went out into the mountains to live as a nomad.

The villagers whispered that Morag, who had been working as a security guard at the manor at the time, had been the one to set the robots free from their programming restraints. She certainly was one of the few who had the skills, and it would explain why she’d been so haunted and silent when she came down from the Big House, the Big Man’s two children hanging off her hands and crying.

And people whispered it a lot.

Meaning, it didn’t surprise anybody when she walked out the farm gates with her rucksack, a sleeping bag, a slingshot, a utilitool, a tinderbox, and her father’s copy of the SAS Survival Guide. Leaving behind her parents and the Big Man’s children, now increasingly regarded as village children, and being known by their proper names of Zeb and Casey. Also leaving behind her phone, and her watch, and her tablet, and her headphones, and her little bundle of tiny picks and tweezers for fixing things.

Morag didn’t think she’d want to touch anything technical ever again.

Twenty-five or thirty years later, Morag sat back on her heels in the mud of what had once been her parents’ farm and said to her robot, “Well, that’s the polytunnel done for, then, Seamus.”

Seamus was occupied with digging a rectangular hole about the size and shape of its own body, using the aluminum claws on its front set of limbs and bracing itself on the other four.

Morag contemplated the rip in the polythene sheet, flapping in the cool early spring wind. Maybe it had been torn by a foraging animal, or maybe it had just given out on its own.

“I don’t know where I’m going to get another,” she said, “and I expect even if I could find one, it’d be expensive as hell. But the plastic-fixer in Pen-y-Groes has patched and patched and patched this one, and there’s no real point in patching it anymore. It’s got too many holes in it to keep the heat in now. So what do I do? Give up growing fruit?”

That was a very worrying idea. She was dependent on the fruits and vegetables she grew for vitamins; they made the regular diet less boring; and she sold any surplus to town-dwellers fresh or as preserves, meaning an income for her and better health for them.

“Ask Owen next door if I can use his?” Owen’s polytunnels were in as bad a shape as hers, and the same was true of everyone else in the village who still used them. A lot of people were facing exactly the same problem as her.

Seamus finished digging its hole. Morag went over to look. Seamus had been doing that a lot lately, and, unlike most of Seamus’ activities, there seemed to be no obvious practical reason. Most of the things it did—patrolling, carrying small objects on its back, warning her of danger, intervening in threatening situations—were exactly what you’d expect from something like Seamus. A repurposed security walkbot that had wandered away from the Big House after the massacre, and eventually found its way, decades later, to the spoil heap behind the village, and from there to Morag’s farm.

Morag revised that mentally. It was a self-repurposed walkbot. She’d taught it some new routines and tricks since it had come to live with her, but it had joined her of its own accord, for its own reasons. And who knew what it had done for the many years it had presumably spent wandering the hills in between.

She supposed she could excuse it a few quirks and eccentricities.

A vague memory surfaced, involving other robots digging holes for no obvious reason. Another data point, but nothing that was helping her fix the polytunnels.

“So,” she asked again, looking at the polytunnel, “what should I do?”

title: Welcome to Kearney by Gary Kloster
excerpt: 9110 words, novelette
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
9110 words, novelette

Ms. Otter came to Kearney when the day was dying, and her shadow ran down the broken road ahead of her like a line of bad luck.

Jeremiah saw it when he paused to get a drink, his stained hands leaving brown fingerprints on his canteen. It was hot—all the days were hot now, and they would be until the atmospheric processors sucked up enough carbon to undo a thousand years of people lighting fire to everything they could find—and he was sweating buckets despite the growing twilight. Jeremiah set the canteen down and gave the dark silhouette a long look until its inhuman outlines were finally clear. Then he turned back to his work. Crouched near the base of the sign, knees complaining, he spread wood stain over the worn boards until the click-swish of footsteps stopped behind him.

“Welcome.”

The word came out soft and slow, slurred by low batteries, and when Jeremiah set down the brush and turned, he could see that the droid was sagging, its fuzzy shoulders slumped, triangular head bowed.

“That’s what it says.” He straightened, knees popping, and the android raised its head, big brown eyes following his movement. Then those eyes went dull, the carefully engineered appearance of awareness draining away with the last of the droid’s power. It fell to the ground and twitched on the grass and broken asphalt, then went still in a furry, untidy heap.

Jeremiah stared at the body for a while, then sighed and looked at the sun. It was low and red, and he was unlikely to finish with the stain before night truly swallowed Nebraska anyway. Picking up his brush and bucket, he walked through the gates back into town, going to fetch a wheelbarrow.

The android was short and light, its struts and guts woven from carbon and nanofiber, but it still wasn’t easy dragging it out of the wheelbarrow and onto the table in the center of Jeremiah’s workshop. But he eventually got the thing arranged on that scarred wooden surface, spread like a carcass beneath the bright work lights.

“Shim,” he said, and on the wall over a pegboard full of tools, a worn wooden effigy opened its glass eyes. “Classify droid.”

There was movement in the web of lights overhead as sensors shifted and whirred, focusing on the heap of dirty fur. “Droid is a product of Pasu Mastercraft, a manufacturer of bespoke domestic service androids.” Shim’s words had the perfect, generic smoothness of a system assistant’s default voice. “Its model number is A54798-O, familiar name Ms. Otter. It is designed to be used as a nanny, to assist with the care of children from infancy to early adolescence.”

A nanny. Jeremiah considered that carefully. A bespoke android was money. A bespoke domestic android rated to care for young children was an entirely different level of money. He walked a slow circle around the table, carefully examining Ms. Otter, pausing occasionally to part the thick fur with his blunt, work-scarred fingers. There were patches of mud stuck to the synthetic hair, and dirt had worked its way down to the skin beneath. The fur was showing signs of fading on the droid’s head and shoulders, the patient work of the sun’s ultraviolet glare, and the skin covering its lower legs was ragged, torn by stones and thorns and refuse.

The whole outer hide would have to come off, Jeremiah thought absently, and the interior integument inspected for tears that might let grit in. His fingers found a lump in the fur that wriggled, and he pulled a dog tick from a tangle of strands. Grit and worse, he thought, taking a hammer from the pegboard below Shim’s wooden head and smashing the parasite with a quick snap of his wrist. He cleaned the mess up with a shop rag, rehung the hammer, and stared off into nothing. Thinking about the raw exhaustion in the droid’s voice, the nuance of cynicism, fear, and hope that had been buried in that one word it had said to him before it had fallen. Emotions he’d heard even through the slurring of the thing’s speech.

title: Editor's Desk: The Future of Dealing with AI Submissions by Neil Clarke
excerpt: Editorial
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Editorial

While I was at Readercon last month, an author asked me how things were going with our attempts to keep “AI” out of the slush pile. It seems like almost no time has passed since I posted an update, but when you are in the thick of things, a sense of time is among the first things to go. In short, it remains a serious problem, the patterns have changed, and we may have to as well. If that’s all you wanted to know, you can stop here and go read some more stories.

The good news is that the adaptations we made to our submissions process (documented at neil-clarke.com) are still functioning well enough that we haven’t had to close submissions since that initial surge. At its peak, our submissions more than doubled due to the high volume of generated works. Back then, the primary driving force behind those submissions was the side-hustle con-artist communities on YouTube, TikTok, and other venues. They routinely told their audiences that they could generate stories and make easy money by submitting them to people like us, or in several cases, us specifically. While these scams continue to drive traffic, they have stopped growing and have become more erratic/spikey in nature. We can always tell when someone makes a new video and sadly, we’ve been unable to get any of the hosting platforms to take action. It’s likely this type of nonsense will continue in some capacity for the foreseeable future.

If that was the extent of our problems, I’d be happy. Those patterns are predictable and easier to catch. The bad news is that a second group of “AI” users has stepped up to fill a growing portion of that void. These people more closely resemble the patterns of our traditional submitting authors, which means they are more likely to bypass our filter and avoid our attempts to deprioritize generated works in the pool.

In many cases, these works have been “co-written” with “AI” or simply given a polishing edit in an attempt to make them less obvious. While these are more sophisticated attempts to get generated works past us, they still display the hallmarks I’ve come to expect, and occasionally, they even leave a prompt or ChatGPT response in the text. Given that I’ve seen some flash and poetry examples of these works find publication elsewhere (the tells are more obvious on longer works), I’d have to rate it as slightly more complicated to recognize. This is one of the few instances I’ll admit that there were some advantages to the flood we received.

As this group grows, and it is growing, it jeopardizes our ability to properly prioritize human writing and maintain open submissions. That’s unacceptable to me.

I was already thinking ahead to this scenario when I wrote my May 2024 editorial on the ethics of using commercial detection tools. Our current process doesn’t involve those tools because when we designed and developed it, detection was still heavily flawed. Adding their products would have decreased the accuracy of the pattern-based solution I had developed. The number of false positives and negatives was simply unacceptable and I observed an even greater error rate when it came to works written by non-native English speakers, a group we want to see participating in the process.

When I wrote that editorial, I could see that things were changing. Today, when I observe various hot-takes about detection on social media, I can’t help but consider them out of touch and stuck in 2023. If you listen to them, those tools should never be used if even one person is flagged incorrectly.

title: Heart of Thunder by Raahem Alvi
excerpt: 8010 words, novelette
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
8010 words, novelette

Present

Damian Marshall was a prisoner to his own brain. He was beating his fist against the glass of his cell, hoping someone could hear that this was not the real him. It was never meant to be this way and, truthfully, he had a heart swelling with love to give.

Damian Marshall was not an evil man, but he was beginning to think that was a lie. No one quite sets out to be evil, he supposed. Malice was a byproduct of some evolutionary self-preserving mammalian instinct. Sometimes evil just happened without intention.

There are mistakes, then there are crimes. And it was difficult to determine the lines between these two forms of evil to definitively categorize his many actions in Ganymede Settler Colony.

“What happened in Ganymede, Mr. Marshall?”

He didn’t know. He really didn’t. His neural augmentations had fucked up the rest of his brain makeup.

“You were exploited. You just need to testify. We can save you from this.”

Damian had always heard voices from his occipital bone. And he was beginning to hear new ones somewhere in the jelly consistency of his brain between all the gray matter. It was a failing neural implant buzzing and coiling inside, screeching, “failing, failing, failing.”

“These were prototype military augmentations. You never should have received them. This is on them.”

He needed someone to take a spear to his skull and calm the electric radiation of a failing augmentation. He needed someone to fix the cybernetics, their corrosive tissue melting into the meat of his organic form. He had given so much of himself to the Corporatocracy.

Where did he start, and where did the augmentations begin?

“Module is reassigning you to Mars Labor Colony 12. That place is privately owned by them. Once you’re there, I can’t help you.”

The thing that identified as Damian Marshall was coiling in an ouroboros-like cycle somewhere within the recesses of his cyborg consciousness.

Maybe Damian was faultless because he wasn’t quite there anymore.

Mars was an unwelcoming little corner of the universe. The freight ship entered through the stratosphere as a missile. And the hostile desert winds set upon it a full-frontal assault.

Damian Marshall was a broken man. But he knew, somewhere between his lungs and his spine, that being broken is just a neutral state for Homo sapiens. Age was slow degradation. Things are made finite for they, by nature, are meant to break. And breaking is all a part of intelligent, conscious design within the neural fields of the universe.

Everything had an end to it. Thus, things had to be exceedingly fragile. So, Damian concluded, his neurological health was one of the many things with a purposeful expiration. It just so happened that his mental health died before his body. So now he carried rot inside his skull. And the necrotic tissue of his sinking self-worth was smelling the innards of their freight ship.

“Grab your bags, grab your supplies, oxygen masks on—”

Damian Marshall was sad. But sadness happens to the best of us.

The problem is when sadness is deserved.

Metal panels collapsed from their place, and wires tossed out. Loose parts struck heads and masks. The gray, cramped chamber where they were belted down sent them into a frenzied maelstrom of rattling and screaming metal.

Damian closed his eyes and felt it drawing closer.

Yes. It. That Thing. The Thing that sends shivers up and down his spine in electric waveform particles, darting in zigzag motions into his neurons. That It—the It that evokes panic and fear in him. That It that still haunts the imprints of his footsteps in Ganymede.

Past

Memories are approximations. They are stretchy, squishy, and fluid things. And, as time stretches to its elastic limit, the mind begins filling certain subsections of time with fiction. And then it eternalizes those fictions as fact. Then fact and fiction fuck and grind against one another until they merge into a twin-headed zombie thing.

“Interview. Damian Samuel Marshall, age 23.”

Damian stared at the lens of the camera, its black glassy exterior a bit judgmental of his rugged state.

title: A Dream of Twin Sunsets by Ryan Cole
excerpt: 5130 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
5130 words, short story

I met him on my first glider mission to the fields beyond the Dandelion. We were both young men then. His patchy beard still blonde, his sunburned cheeks not yet wrinkled from the years out in the wild. His name not yet carved into the secret prayers I whispered—every night, into my pillow—once my wife went to sleep.

“I’m Buzz,” he’d said to me, the gentle zzz like the bee swarms that darkened the pink skies; the giant bees we’d imitated since we first came to this planet, many generations past. Studying their flight patterns. Shooting off in our glider-pods from our Dandelion home base. Poisoning the flower fields that for years had poisoned us, cut us down from two thousand to less than two hundred, the last surviving exploration colony—as far as we knew.

The way he spoke, the way he laughed, it was all so very . . . different. Relaxed, like he hadn’t had to ration his every meal. Had to hide from the twin violet suns overhead, that could melt us to the bone. Had to eke out a life under Dandelion martial law, wear the polished Corporal Journey tag they’d pinned to my uniform only two days before, that I could never take off, no matter how much I wanted.

But we were a society of rules, first and foremost. Rules to protect us. To keep us alive. To keep from being torn to shreds by the next pollen storm, crushed to dust by the mile-high fields of thick grass, the feral world we’d come so far to try to make our own. Even though it would never let us.

“We don’t deserve it,” he’d said to me on our last night together. A night I would cling to for twenty long years. Remembering the warmth of his arm around my waist, his breath in my ear, the danger if the Dandelion ever found us in his glider-pod, so far off-grid. Him a deserter; me a newly minted officer.

Even now, as I keyed in my access credentials, and I stepped into the elevator, and I rode down the Dandelion’s hundreds of metal floors—to the long-emptied food bunker and the prison cells underneath—I couldn’t let go: of the freedom in his smile; the twinkle in his blue eyes as he looked up at the suns, only seeing their beauty where I’d been taught to see death. And I wondered if, today, he’d be the same as he was back then. The only man I had ever loved. The man who had saved me. The man who—in just a few hours—I would have to kill.

Twenty winters earlier: when the bees hadn’t yet crawled out from their hives in the mountains, and the fields that surrounded us—closing in the Dandelion for hundreds of miles—were whipped by the wind gusts that never seemed to end. An ocean of yellow grass bent near to breaking.

I hunched over the blinking-red controls of my glider-pod, the tight ceiling of the pod pressing down on my head. Hands sweaty on the joystick, I flew toward the head of a newly bloomed flower—its pollen-streaked petals as large as the sun—fighting the wind as it dragged me back down. Reassuring myself that I was safe, I could do this. What I’d done a dozen times in the training simulations I’d recently completed, the false safety of the Dandelion’s bunkers, now many miles behind me.

But the wind was too strong, the pollen too thick, blanketing the glass of my pod’s window screen. I couldn’t make it to the top, still half a mile down the stem. Too low to plant the poison-laced pollen I carried, that would slowly kill the flower, kill the bees that came to feed it, completing the assignment I’d been trained for since birth—along with the other few dozen officers who remained.

Kill, or be killed. The only life I’d ever known. The life the Dandelion required. A life from which I very much wished I could escape.

title: Vwooom! by Uchechukwu Nwaka
excerpt: 1390 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
1390 words, short story

The suit is too tight. Pinches just a little too uncomfortably around your neck, like phantom gnarly fingers constricting your windpipe. You swallow a lump. It’s only nerves. A bead of sweat zigzags down the side of your face, distracting you from all the readings in your helmet’s HUD. Your recently modified vertebral implants feel like a caterpillar crawling down your back. Skittering. Biting. Chewing.

You’ve not needed the augments since the Amadiohas were decommissioned. You think that you should have removed them. That’s what they suggest at the rehabilitation home for the ex-pilots anyway. You only attend to humor Pa Ebube, but you know you’ll never let go of the reinforced skeleton. Not with the power it brings you. How else would you have survived all those brawls in the Pits?

How else would you have been eligible for this trial flight into the Eye of Abstinence?

The cockpit is a glass coffin. The engine hums like the purr of a feline. A primal hunter stalking its prey. The vibrations seep into your bones. Your pupils dilate as the world stretches before you—concentric rings of white lights that form the tunnel of the accelerator gates. Electromagnetic fields pulse, and your heartbeat flutters. Your breath escapes in shallow puffs. The engine roars behind you, but you do not hear it over the rush of blood pounding against your eardrums. Your bloodstream is flooded with catecholamines.

It is the same feeling as being uplinked into the Amadioha—the fifteen-foot mechanical organism of utter destruction. When you swing your fist, the massive metallic limbs pierce through another mecha in an earsplitting explosion. Ideally, within the Amadioha, pilots are not supposed to see the pool of blood beneath the tanks they have trampled below their feet like steel ants. However, there is something different about your sync rate. Your tragic need to hyper-focus. Which means that you see the corpses of your enemies—once brothers, separated by tribe and prejudice—littered across former cityscapes, in a civil war labeled The Separation by poets who escaped conscription.

You still see the blood when you close your eyes.

It is why you don’t blink as you stare into the darkness. The gullet of the Eye.

The war ended over a decade ago. The iron angels that crushed the Earth beneath their heels at the command of their faceless masters in the space stations suspended in the heavens have been turned to scrap. The pilots have long been left to fend for themselves. You trade one master for another. Champion of the Pits. You ignore messages from Pa Ebube and delete his holos before you can see the worry behind his eyes. The crow’s feet that you’ve always known him to have. His silver hair has begun to seem thinner, but didn’t everyone lose something in The Separation? The world is no longer like the days of your youth. Back when you started living in Pa Ebube’s house, with his family of five. Your parents had died in a tribal terror attack, and somehow, he’d taken you in. Even with the economy tightening like a noose around the people’s necks.

Not unlike the helmet around your head now. The hangman’s noose around your neck.

He wants you to get a degree.

You dive into the etherspace for hours on that second-hand—maybe fifth-hand—headpiece, working on virtual workspace schoolwork. Most times, you’re trying to pretend like you do not hear Aunty’s discontent with Pa Ebube’s decision to adopt you. So many credits are being spent on your education. Deep down, you believe her. Would it not be better for the household if you spent your time working as a salesboy in her restaurant, instead of wasting precious hours painting caricatures on a glorified Game Boy? If Pa Ebube chooses to funnel the money going into your art degree into Aunty’s business, then everybody gains. After all, things are harder by the day with growing tensions. Insecurity. Tribal attacks. What would an orphaned artist have to offer, doing a job that any AI could?

Also, what does it matter if the thoughts originated in the razor-sharp tongue of Aunty’s ire? They are yours now, no?

title: The Rebellion is Real: 1984 and The Handmaid's Tale in 2025 by Carrie Sessarego
excerpt: Non-Fiction
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Non-Fiction

Rebellious speculative fiction gives us works that provide a compelling combination of striking imagery and broad reach that become real-life tools for protestors today. One of these works is 1984, a novel that gave us the language we needed to identify the tools that oppressive regimes use to control their subjects. Another is The Handmaid’s Tale, which both as a novel and as a television show gave us powerful imagery to use as a form of resistance. Both novels explore strategies of oppression as well as resistance that are relevant today.

The novel 1984 was published by George Orwell in 1949. Although there have been several adaptations of the novel, most famously the movie version released in 1984, this essay concerns the novel exclusively. Set in a dystopian world, the novel depicts Winston, a low-level government official, as he tries to maintain a sense of self and autonomy in the face of overwhelming totalitarian forces.

In this world, the country of Oceania is locked in an endless and mutually destructive war with the rest of the world. Oceania is ruled by The Party under the leadership of a mysterious figure known as Big Brother. Every room in Oceania (or, at a minimum, London, the city in which the events of the book take place) is under constant surveillance through television screens and other equipment. Children are trained to spy on their parents, and adults spy on one another.

While some of the control of its citizens is physical, most of the control exerted by the government is psychological and involves the government’s efforts to control its citizens’ perception of reality. Citizens become accustomed to “The Ministry of Peace,” which controls war, and “The Ministry of Love,” which concerns torture. They are forced to read and repeat the slogans, “War is Peace,” “Freedom is Slavery,” and “Ignorance is Strength.” Historical records and newscasts are altered to paint Big Brother in a wholly positive light. An example of the surrealism of life under Big Brother comes early in the book:

This was not illegal (nothing was illegal, since there were no longer any laws), but if detected it was reasonably certain that it would be punished by death, or at least by twenty-five years in a forced-labour camp.

The forms of resistance displayed in 1984 are primarily inward—the battle to preserve one’s sense of individuality in a world in which “Nothing was your own except the few cubic centimetres inside your skull.” Winston begins his rebellion by committing “thoughtcrimes,” entertaining thoughts that are out of alignment with the teachings of Big Brother. His rebellion escalates even further when he begins writing a diary.

When Winston and a woman named Julia begin a forbidden affair, it represents a massive escalation of rebellion. Sex is supposed to be a joyless exercise conducted for the purposes of procreation, not pleasure:

The aim of the party was not merely to prevent men and women from forming loyalties which it might not be able to control. Its real, undeclared purpose was to remove all pleasure from the sexual act . . . sexual intercourse was to be looked on as a slightly disgusting minor operation, like having an enema.

Above all, Winston and Julia’s affair is illicit because these emotions and these acts occur without permission. Their feelings for each other, emotional and sexual, exist beyond Big Brother. The energy they spend making love is energy not used toward The Party’s goals. Their time together is spent where and when they believe no one can see them, and they feel things that Big Brother did not tell them to feel.

title: Women, Technology, and the Future: A Conversation with Brenda Cooper by Arley Sorg
excerpt: Interview
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Interview

Brenda Cooper was born in Encino, CA, and grew up in Hidden Hills. “I’m a classic California ‘Valley Girl’ who moved south to Orange County at ten. Then I spent most of High School ditching class to surf beaches like Doheny and Redondo Beach, and Trestles that the Beach Boys sang about.” Cooper started reading early and remembers reading the newspaper every day with her dad. “When I went to kindergarten, they gave me a picture book. I came home furious, saying I never wanted to go to school again if they weren’t willing to teach me anything.” Around the same age, she started writing poetry.

Cooper started working at age twelve, harvesting eggs and delivering them to houses around the neighborhood—on a unicycle. “At one point, while I was a teenage runaway, I worked on a worm farm in Eugene, Oregon. We captured night crawlers with flashlights at midnight and dug in rabbit poop for red wrigglers at noon. This only lasted a few months. I liked it, though.”

Cooper earned a BA in management information systems at California State University, Fullerton. “Dad said he’d pay for college if I didn’t get an English degree. He said I needed to pay bills, and the humanities wasn’t going to do that. For context, he’s a rocket scientist, and he was right. At the time, I was a single teenage mom with a one year old. I have paid all our bills. My son is now a forty-five-year-old successful firefighter.” Over the years, she stayed involved in writing communities, often learning and developing writing skills along the way. She helped Steven Barnes with his Lifewriting classes, studied with Dean Wesley Smith and Kristine Kathryn Rusch, and attended Patrick Swenson’s Rainforest Writers Retreat many times. Even after her professional and personal successes, including already publishing a number of books, Cooper returned to education in her fifties, earning her MFA from Stonecoast. “I had SO MUCH FUN. Loved it. I got to study with Martín Espada, this fiery, brilliant Puerto Rican poet. When he performed his poetry, he utterly owned the room. I also got to work with Debra Marquart, Rick Bass, Elizabeth Hand, Nancy Holder, and more.”

Cooper’s work—nonfiction, poetry, and fiction—began appearing in publications in the early 2000s. Some of her earliest published fiction pieces were cowritten with Larry Niven, such as debut short story “Ice and Mirrors” (Asimov’s Science Fiction, February 2001). It wouldn’t be long before she was selling fiction as a soloist. In 2002, she had the story “Recovery” in The Salal Review, and in 2003, “Linda’s Dragon” was published in Analog Science Fiction and Fact, as well as “Touches the Earth” in anthology Sun in Glory and Other Tales of Valdemar (DAW). She was a Sturgeon finalist for 2004 Analog story “Savant Songs.”

In 2005, with a fair number of short stories in respected magazines and anthologies, Cooper’s debut novel Building Harlequin’s Moon came out with Tor, again cowritten with Niven. Her solo debut The Silver Ship and the Sea was published by Tor in 2007, earning her a Golden Duck nomination and an Endeavour Award win. She also received a Philip K. Dick nomination and won another Endeavour Award for 2015 novel Edge of Dark (Pyr). To date, Brenda Cooper has over eighty short stories out, two collections, and thirteen novels.

Writing has always been central to Brenda Cooper’s life. “When I was in Junior High, I won the seventh-grade skateboarding contest. I was the only girl who entered. Other than that, I’ve had various awards in my tech career. There is one story worth telling. A major tech magazine gave me an award in front of at least a few hundred people at a tech conference. I was pleased. Then I stopped in a Barnes & Noble on the way home and picked up Gardner Dozois’ Year’s Best. And there, I found one of my stories had made it to his honorable mention list. Not into the book, not into his overview, just into the long list at the back of the book. I was so happy I sat down in the middle of the aisle and bawled.”

title: Tactical Ballgowns and Genre Turduckens: A Conversation with Fran Wilde by Arley Sorg
excerpt: Interview
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Interview

Fran Wilde was born in Philadelphia, PA. She spent many summers traveling back and forth from Philadelphia to Hopkinsville, KY. She began to read and write early on, and storytelling was a tradition in her family’s household. She spent extensive time in the library, eventually discovering bookstores and all they had to offer. Her family kept classics as well as engineering books and other nonfiction texts, but Wilde went out of her way to explore science fiction.

In high school, Fran Wilde studied art and learned to design jewelry. She went to the University of Virginia and earned an English degree, studying writing and literature with an emphasis on poetry, as well as on Milton and eighteenth-century literature. She earned an MFA in poetry from Warren Wilson College and later earned another master’s at the University of Baltimore in information architecture and interaction design. In 2011, Wilde attended Viable Paradise, followed by Taos Toolbox in 2012.

Fran Wilde has been publishing poetry since the nineties. She made a splash in genre fiction with short stories “Everlasting” and “Everyone Loves a Hero” in Daily Science Fiction in 2011, followed by “Without” in Nature in 2012. This was just the beginning: she has over fifty short stories published at a range of notable venues, and has racked up extensive accolades, including Nebula, World Fantasy, and Hugo awards finalist and Eugie winner “Clearly Lettered in a Mostly Steady Hand” (Uncanny 9-10/2017); as well as Locus, Nebula, and Hugo awards finalist “A Catalog of Storms” (Uncanny 1-2/2019).

Wilde’s longer fiction has similarly received a wide range of recognition. For example, debut novel Updraft was published by Tor in 2015, launching the Bone Universe series. Updraft was a Nebula and Dragon awards finalist, won a Compton Crook Award, and secured Wilde an Andre Norton Nebula Award. Wilde has published several novels so far, including Locus Award finalist Horizon (Tor 2017) as well as Lodestar finalist and Andre Norton Nebula Award winner Riverland (Amulet 2019).

Other adventures include working as a sailing instructor, programmer, web designer, and more. Fran Wilde has taught at Vermont College of Fine Arts and St. Mary’s College of Maryland. She was also the director of the genre fiction MFA concentration at Western Colorado University. In 2022, she cofounded and still coedits digital magazine The Sunday Morning Transport, which has earned her another World Fantasy finalist nod—in the Special Award, Non-Professional category—as well as a Locus Award finalist spot for Best Editor.

Fran Wilde lives in Maryland with her family. Collection A Catalog of Storms is due from Fairwood Press this month, and novel

is due from Erewhon next month.

You earned an MFA in poetry and later went on to teach and run MFA programs. A number of notable SFF authors have earned MFAs, but some have talked about difficult experiences with programs or have mentioned instructors who frowned on SFF. What are your thoughts about MFAs specifically for up-and-coming genre writers?

I did get my first master’s in poetry (second one is in information architecture and interaction design)! I studied poetry with Heather McHugh, Eleanor Wilner, Larry Levis, Joan Aleshire, and Marianne Boruch (as well as Rita Dove, undergrad) at Warren Wilson College.

I am still close with many in my MFA cohort, and we cheer each other on, no matter what field we’re working in. That, plus engaging in a close study of language and structure, was one of the joys of doing an MFA.

I think there’s more willingness to encourage speculative writers in many MFA programs now—and that’s a wonderful thing.

The best advice I can give to anyone considering an MFA, beyond using the time to read widely and stay curious, is to look at the structure of the program and make sure it works for you, as well as talking to recent grads and current students. You can get a good feel for what the program’s like on the ground that way, which is important, as it is a big investment of time, energy, and money.

title: Move over fashion week: Chanel and Dior soft launch creations at Venice film festival
excerpt: After a year of musical chairs in the fashion industry, September is poised to be one of its biggest show months ever, with debut collections from 15 creative directors.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
After a year of musical chairs in the fashion industry, September is poised to be one of its biggest show months ever, with debut collections from 15 creative directors.

The Guardian’s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link. Learn more.

Rather than waiting for the catwalk, over the past 10 days brands including Chanel and Dior have given themselves a head start at the Venice film festival, using its starry red carpets and even gondolas to soft launch looks from their newly installed designers.

Unlike the Oscars, which is one night of intense red-carpet scrutiny, or the Cannes film festival, which comes with strict rules, the focus at Venice is very much on notable art house films.

With the pressure off, it allows designers, stylists and their Hollywood clients the opportunity to have a bit more fun. Amanda Seyfried even borrowed the same Versace look from Julia Roberts. A triumph for sustainability or a marketing stunt? Either way, it was front-page news.

Jonathan Anderson, who took over at Dior in June, teased more than a dozen looks on actors including Greta Lee and Alba Rohrwacher before his womenswear debut in Paris next month. Lee wore a deconstructed minidress that riffed on the brand’s signature bar jacket, while Rohrwacher wore a navy gown with a padded bustle.

Meanwhile, Tilda Swinton hinted at what we can expect from Matthieu Blazy, the French-Belgian designer who recently landed the top job at Chanel, when she stepped off a water taxi wearing loosely cut white trousers and a short-sleeved blouse featuring tiny shimmering interlocking CC buttons.

Henrik Lischke, the senior fashion features editor at Grazia, likens this new preview strategy to the press tour of the Barbie film in 2023. “That proved that the more hype you create, the more attention you get. These fashion brands are giving us a glimpse of what to expect,” he said. “It gets people excited long before a look even hits the catwalk.”

It can also catapult relatively unknown names into the spotlight. In April, when it was announced Dario Vitale would be taking over from Donatella Versace, he was a designer only industry insiders were familiar with. But this week he was the talk of the lido, thanks to that sneak peek via Roberts and Seyfried.

Pop stars such as Taylor Swift are known for planting Easter eggs, hidden clues about future projects for fans to decipher. Paparazzi shots of actors on set are used as unofficial teasers. And now it appears fashion designers are embracing the art of the promotional sneak peek too.

Fashion’s new soft launch was first embraced by the actor Timothée Chalamet, who wore Haider Ackermann’s first outfit for Tom Ford to the Golden Globes, two months before the designer’s debut show. He also wore Sarah Burton’s first menswear look for Givenchy, a butter-yellow suit, to the Oscars days before her inaugural Paris show. Vicky Krieps and Julianne Moore have also worn previews of Louise Trotter’s Bottega Veneta.

But similar to how on-set images have been blamed for ruining movie magic, could these early teasers backfire? Some online users have accused Versace of becoming boring, while others say Anderson’s purposefully chaotic pieces for Dior do not exactly scream Hollywood glamour.

Amy Odell, a fashion commentator and author of Gwyneth: The Biography, says while designers will be aware of early criticism, it is important to remember “not every look is for everybody”. As for disclosing too much, Odell is not worried. “I don’t think a whole lot is given away by one or two looks at a film festival – I view it as a nice teaser of what’s to come, an amuse bouche versus a big spoiler.”

title: A Shaky Bridge by Marissa Lingen
excerpt: 2900 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
2900 words, short story

Afterward, no one in Casey’s family could say when their feelings about the neural bridge implant started to sour. None of them—Casey least of all—wanted to see the signs at first. Humans are extremely good at not seeing things they don’t want to see, and the neural bridge had been the next thing to miraculous after her father’s stroke, restoring his speech without even a week of therapy or a hint of a slur, letting him walk again steadily, without a cane.

But gradually she couldn’t help but notice that her mother was pale, had more lines around her mouth, and was less likely to speak but more likely to snap or cry than previously, and finally she took her aside to ask what was the matter.

“Nothing, nothing.”

“Don’t give me that, Mom, it’s obvious something’s bothering you.”

“I don’t want to worry you with it.”

Casey put a hand on her hip. “Do I look unworried now?”

“It’s just . . . some of the things your father says. They aren’t like him. I know they said the neural bridge was supposed to handle everything from the stroke, but . . . it’s not your dad, Case.”

Her hand dropped. She tried to keep her voice light, positive. “They also said there could be personality changes after a stroke. Even with the neural bridge.”

“He recites the ads for MindBridge Corp’s other products verbatim,” said her mother flatly.

Casey felt her mouth drop open. She made herself close it.

“It’s not that he’s losing his temper more than before, or crying, or any of the stuff I read about happening after a stroke. It’s just . . . MindBridge Corp ads, and sometimes other ideas about MindBridge Corp and Spencer Rawling.”

Casey wished she didn’t recognize the name of the CEO of MindBridge Corp. She certainly had no idea who was the CEO of the company who made her shoes or her glasses. But Spencer Rawling had made himself unavoidable in the public sphere in the last few years, always finding some way to put himself front and center of every new product launch or even mild update. She felt petty for hating his face. Also, she still hated his face anyway.

“Dad hates Spencer Rawling,” she said now.

“I know he does,” said her mother, “but sometimes he doesn’t talk like it.”

Casey resolved to pay more attention, but it didn’t take long to come up with her own list of things her father said that sounded really unlike him. Now that she knew what to look for—his voice was the same, but his phrasing was different, very different. She asked her younger brother Norris to help her address it with them, even though she knew he hated talking about health stuff, or emotions, or anything personal.

“I think we have to take this seriously, for Dad’s sake and for Mom’s,” she said.

Norris squirmed. “Maybe he just feels genuinely glad to have it. Grateful. I mean, I’m glad he has it. So maybe he’s feeling differently about The Spence.”

“I have been,” said Casey. “You know I have. But this goes beyond that. I think we have to talk to Dad about it.”

“Oh joy,” Norris muttered. She gave him her patented big sister look, and he fell reluctantly into line, trudging into the living room where they had always had family conversations.

“Dad, you’ve been saying some stuff lately that worries us,” Casey started, when her mom and Norris showed no sign of starting.

“What kind of stuff, gooferoo?” he asked.

She smiled despite herself. Thirty years old, and she was still gooferoo and Caserino to her dad. But she couldn’t be distracted, this was too important. “Stuff about MindBridge Corp, Dad. About Spencer Rawling.”

“Like what?”

“Yesterday you said that Spencer Rawling was the best thing that ever happened to humanity and deserved a medal,” her mother said. “You never used to say that about someone with his track record of labor abuses and human rights violations.”

“No, he’s always—I think—did I really say that?”

“You really did, and it wasn’t the first thing that made me worry about you.”
