title: And The Planet Loved Him by L Chan
excerpt: 3290 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
3290 words, short story

I’ve been here a few weeks, and the sunsets never get old. The blue sun scintillates off the spore miasma, glittering into fractal rainbows. The worst part is the waiting. We’re so far off the grid that by the time the distress signal relays back to someone that could authorize the funds requisition for a rescue, there’s a good chance that I’d already run out of air or food or both. We still see the light of stars long gone supernova in the sky. I’m dead already; I just haven’t gotten the memo.

And this is all before my deceased husband’s voice crackles on the radio from outside the habitat.

Corporate Headquarters smells like many things. Coffee, emanating from mug rings on polymer tabletops. Designer fabric. Esoteric colognes brewed with synthetic ambergris from long-extinct cetaceans. These are surface smells, olfactory wallpaper, because what corporate smells mostly like is desperation. The walls and fixtures were once pristine white to reflect corporate values, but they’d since been yellowed and bubbled by the narcotic smoke from pocket vaporizers.

Philbert is doing a hard sell. That’s not really his name. Ewan and I call all corporate salespeople Philbert. They’re always being swapped out, and it’s proven too difficult to remember each one.

“ . . . so headquarters wants to maintain research rights to the system, which you’ll notice has an anomalous planetary formation. As you can see, there is a planetoid at a diametrically opposed orbit to our target planet and . . . ”

“L3 orbits are in unstable equilibrium without station keeping inputs,” says Ewan. He doesn’t want to give Philbert the satisfaction of parroting the science. Classic Ewan. Except Ewan is dead, and we aren’t in a mission brief, because I’m obviously dying alone on the planet we’re talking about. “You’re dead,” I tell Ewan. Philbert continues his monologue about the discoveries on the planet, the vast beds of polychromatic fungus, the toxic atmosphere. I look at my husband, the slight bulges where middle years had blurred the sharp muscled edge of his youth, the lines at the corners of his eyes, and the slight breathlessness when he showed up the corporate guy. I see all this, and I know the person there isn’t my husband.

“You’re not him, aren’t you.”

“The colony designated Ewan Roberts is in Communion with the Consensus. Our colony designation in your syntax is Mycosis, and our function is to be in Communion with you.”

Philbert drones on about the habitat, how it’s going to be state of the art. We know what’s not being spoken about the contract. The company needs to have a research presence so that their rights to the planet don’t lapse. Accounts would run the interminable process of crunching profitability numbers while the extractive division chomps at the bit. The company wants to eat after all, it just needs the bean counters to sign off on the meal.. We’re just going to be seat warmers while the bean counters do their thing. That’s what Ewan and I discussed the night after this. But here and now, we’re stuck in a memory, and there’s something inside my husband’s body, speaking to me in a dead voice.

“Mycosis is the process of fungal infection. Why are we here?”

Ewan smiles, and I’m put in mind of the empty carapace of a beetle, hollowed out with its nervous system being puppeted by a fungus. I want to reach over and tear at his face with my fingers to see if it comes off.

“To commune. To determine your purpose here. To understand you.”

title: Sleeper by R.T. Ester
excerpt: 4940 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
4940 words, short story

Syd got seven grand to sign over the rights to her virtual clone. The broker she used put up billboards promoting additional payment each time it was leased. When I came home to her apartment and she told me, it felt like an ambush. Money was tight, and there she was to remind me, giving up something of hers I wouldn’t have imagined she would when we first met.

At her desk that night, I sat alone and gave the view through her window all the emotion I could muster after sixteen hours at the training center, plugged in with virtual constructs ready for life on the outside. Through the rain pattering on the glass, floating billboards roamed. The Envoy Church had just announced the opening of a new school, and its ads flickered against the clouds. I was raised in an Envoy school. One of the billboards came close to the window and made me nostalgic for early mornings inside a cafeteria with the Envoy Hologram in its midst.

The image projected from this billboard was of the Envoy herself. Her indigo skin was supposed to have resulted from upgrades to her genome. The hooded robe she wore was black like vacuum, radiant against the smog that had settled before the rain. Her smile lingered on the glass. Her eyes were hidden under a color-shifting veil that draped down over her face. She was saying what she always said.

“Bend,” I echoed back. Absent-minded.

Syd slept and tossed about behind me while the mattress we shared inside her one-room apartment jostled at the chair legs under my weight. In a haste, she’d done what the Envoy Church preached as the honorable thing for people like us. I wanted none of it.

We were just two kids out of countless who ran away from school and wound up trafficked to virtual reality black sites shortly after. But even out here, years later, it seemed a program was running with the purpose of killing us slowly. Where no one would see.

I crawled in beside her and bit down the urge to wake her and tell her she was making a mistake. She’d heard me say it countless times. The money would cover the first installment for her brother Antwan’s cancer treatment. Enough that night to make me reflect on a still-standing offer from the Revenge.

When we were old enough to memorize it, we heard the Envoy’s story the way it was written by her most devout followers. Headlines circulated at first of a plane crash. Its lone survivor had left no trace of her existence prior to being discovered amid the wreckage, and when she was able to speak, she made detailed predictions about world events that all came true.

“Ever done anything like this?”

Unable to sleep, I’d left Syd in her apartment and was now presented with a question that chilled my spine as I sipped my vodka straight and, looking out over the verandah next to the bar, tried to ignore the Revenge contact looming like a column behind me. To answer, I would have to know what the Revenge was really offering.

The contact’s name was Edgar, and he’d first approached me while I was walking home from the center. He had a soft voice that went sour whenever he talked about the school he attended, but it was just good to hear from someone who hadn’t forgotten what life was like on the Envoy compounds where, as children, we were plugged in for twelve hours every day, getting acquainted with clones of the Envoy and learning all we ever knew from them.

“They don’t expect any of you to succeed, but they keep trying,” Edgar said.

I nodded. “And it’s still half up front?”

I wanted to know it was real, if nothing else. Not a dream that began when we met and had since imposed itself on my waking life.

Edgar walked up gingerly and looked me in the eye. “No one’s touching the Envoy,” he said, picking his words. “But if it’s you who does it, then it’s you.”

“What does that mean?”

title: Memories Are Only Valuable if They Can Be Lost by Ai Jiang
excerpt: 5530 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
5530 words, short story

THE FLOATING CITY

Hovering around the corner of every alley you’d slinked along the shadows of was a holographic infinite snake—the upcoming New Year’s zodiac symbol. It was also something you saw every day for the past month through the small window of the factory you worked in, or not so much a factory, but a mind mine, really. Sometimes, you suspected that every time you thought about something outside of work, they’d wipe a bit of your memory during your hours. Small snippets only—just enough that you wouldn’t notice or miss the missing memories. You waved the hologram aside and headed toward the city’s only travel agency, which looked more like a safe within a bank than an actual business.

In front of the travel agency glared many adverts for different locations on the mainland—Shanghai, Beijing, Fuzhou, Chengdu—with train prices that were marked up much higher in preparation for the New Year so they could call it a sale when they lowered it back to the regular cost it displayed in the months leading up to the celebration. But it didn’t matter, because to ride a train run by the Zodiac Travel Lines was always expensive, and to make things worse, it was the only mode of transportation out of the floating city, almost as though the city heads were telling the workers they were trapped without explicitly stating it. But it was obvious, because shortly after you arrived, you realized why your father couldn’t contact you when you were still at home and why you, too, couldn’t contact your family now. It was not allowed. It was to keep you focused, to keep you disconnected. The trains also only ran during the New Year, the only time of the year when the floating city shut down, to transport workers back to their homes on the mainland.

You used to look at the prices online, in incognito mode, though it didn’t much matter because the Zodiac Travel Lines was the only website you could access, and you were sure they were tracking your search history anyhow. It was only an illusion of choice. They installed a chip into your mind that allowed all the functions of a computer and phone so that you wouldn’t need to carry around a device. You left behind your cell with the cracked screen and a system that had been slowing down with each update; so much so, you ended up turning off the manual update option for a year, and it had all but become unusable because all the apps on it required the newer system. You should’ve brought it with you, even if you knew you wouldn’t be able to use it.

You wondered if your ba stood in front of the Zodiac Travel Lines agency, too, before he disappeared. They said many of those who came to the city do. Because they failed, and they didn’t want to show their faces in front of their families out of pride. Others whispered rumors about those who left, finding new families, creating new lives. You knew that wasn’t true because in this city, it wasn’t possible, because everyone was moving so quickly, so focused on their work, that there was no time for anything else. Others said it was because they took their own lives, knowing they’d never be able to return.

You weren’t sure what happened to your ba. You only knew the money stopped coming when you turned seventeen and your younger sister ten, and you had no choice but to drop out of school. At eighteen, you came here to work to send money back to your ma and mei, but you also came here to look for your ba. Yet, when you asked those who you worked with, others in the floating city who would spare you the time, no one knew of your ba. Or perhaps, he simply didn’t want to be found. So, you stopped asking. Or perhaps it was the factory that consistently made you forget to ask as soon as you remembered.

title: Sea of Fertility by Bella Han
excerpt: 17180 words, novelette
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
17180 words, novelette

My big brother vanished in the virtual city of Laputa, leaving no trace behind. I sit up, sweating, for a moment convinced I’m still dreaming. Feed globes drift in, flooding my vision with news. The man beside me opens his eyes, about to speak, but teleports away at my gloomy expression. I’ve forgotten his username.

I wave off the auto-generated music and get out of bed, stepping onto a mess of candy wrappers. The only thing I remember from last night is the Senso candies—the latest masterwork I created in the lab, featuring an exceptional sensation of pain. But they’re still missing something. I know that—I always know that they’re no match for real feelings. I had wanted to ask Brother for suggestions, even though he never liked my research. But just now, before I was fully awake, the system asked me, “Who is your brother?”

I reach out to search manually. My smart choker glows, and a search icon appears in the air. “Weilan Yu,” I say his name.

Data streams through the transparent choker while the translucent icon spins dizzily. After a moment, words appear:

“User not found.”

My heart sinks. I search for his current username, “Azure,” then his former one, “Ray.” No results. Nothing on his band, “Polar Day,” or his music. No past interactions with him in my social history. No trace of his user ID. Brother has evaporated from the city of Laputa, as if he never existed.

My hand drops. Through the panoramic windows, cloud shadows shifted across my face. Beyond this empty room lies a city of eternal daytime. From this height, the view is dominated by a colossal ember-shaped building, followed by a tower that rises like clustered crystal. At the bases of the skyscrapers, Eighth Avenue swarms with people, flowing like a river of pixels. Hot topics rise like balloons, filling the sky, while outdated ones fall like shooting stars. The sky is perpetually blue, crowned with radiant summer clouds. This is Laputa, the greatest city ever built.

But now, a bug has been revealed. People don’t vanish in Laputa. If they go bankrupt, their names are struck through, and they start over with a new account. If they die, their names turn gray. A twinge of anxiety pricks me—it’s been a while since I last felt anything this strong. No, it can’t be serious. Brother must be playing a new trick.

I dash to the wall, which transforms into a mirror, displaying all my available looks. I tap my favorite and shift into it: a high ponytail, a sporty-chic dress, and sneakers.

“To Brother’s,” I command.

“ERROR: LINK BROKEN.”

The warning appears in the air, then fades like traces of rain.

Of course. I let out a dry laugh. I don’t remember the coordinates of his apartment, but at least—I glance at the urban labyrinth and command, “To Stellar Plaza”—I know how to get there on foot.

When I arrived at Laputa for college, Brother showed me around the city. Back then, he was called Ray, and there was a light in his eyes. He wore a cool bomber jacket, while I was stuck with the goofy default jumpsuit. Starting from Stellar Plaza, we set off to see the world.

Buildings rose into the sky, gleaming like gems. Twelve spotlight avenues radiated from the Plaza, bustling with all kinds of weirdos, some not even human. People paraded along the roads, each step paired with a sweet tinkling in the air. Fun topics danced in the clouds, while Off-islands dotted the sky like a planetary ring. I couldn’t help bouncing with excitement, and Brother couldn’t hide his smile. “See? This is the paradise we dreamed of as kids!”

Seven years passed since then, and the city has changed. Along Second Avenue, skyscrapers crystallize overnight, only to dissolve months later. The Horn of Plenty is gone, replaced by the fancier, pricier Carat. Story Factory has vanished, along with its successor, Black Light Theater, replaced by Shard Gallery, a twisted mirror of a building.

title: Meera Sodha’s recipe for kidney bean and sweetcorn curry
excerpt: My grandmother, Narmada Lakhani, passed away earlier this year aged 92. Well, we think she was 92, but no one recorded her birth date, so we can only estimate. What we do know about her, though, is that she had a very cheeky laugh, and that she loved lager tops, penny slot mac…
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
My grandmother, Narmada Lakhani, passed away earlier this year aged 92. Well, we think she was 92, but no one recorded her birth date, so we can only estimate. What we do know about her, though, is that she had a very cheeky laugh, and that she loved lager tops, penny slot machines and tucking £10 notes down her bra, ready to hand out to an unsuspecting grandchild as a gift. She never asked if I was happy, only if I’d eaten well, which I assume to her were the same thing. At this time of year, eating well for her meant tucking into sweetcorn, so, in her memory, I’m going to do the same.

Kidney bean and sweetcorn curry

Prep 10 min
Cook 40 minServes

4

3 tbsp rapeseed oil 25 fresh curry leaves (ie, from about 2 sprigs)

1 tsp cumin seeds

1 brown onion, peeled and chopped

2cm x 2cm piece fresh ginger, peeled and finely grated

4 garlic cloves, peeled and minced

1-2 green finger chillies, or 1 tsp kashmiri chilli powder

400g tin finely chopped tomatoes, or passata

1½ tsp garam masala
2

2

400g tins kidney beans in water, drained and rinsed

1¾ tsp fine sea salt
150g frozen sweetcorn, defrosted

150g frozen sweetcorn

Chapa

tis and greek yoghurt, to serve

Heat the oil in a large, deep-sided frying pan and test it’s up to temperature by dipping in a wooden spoon: if bubbles form around the spoon immediately, the oil is ready. Drop in the curry leaves and cumin seeds, leave them to splutter for a minute, then add the onion. Cook, stirring frequently, for about 10 minutes, until the onion is glossy and soft enough to cut with a wooden spoon; don’t skimp on the time here.

Add the ginger, garlic and chilli to the softened onions and cook, stirring, for a couple of minutes. Tip in the tomatoes and leave to cook for eight or so minutes, until the mix splits and the tomatoes start to release oil back into the pan.

Add the garam masala, stir for a minute, then add the kidney beans, salt, 250ml cold water and the sweetcorn, and bring to a boil. Turn down the heat to a simmer and leave to cook for a further 10 minutes.

Serve with chapatis and thick Greek yoghurt.

title: Blind date: ‘He didn’t find it weird that I arrived at the date using a homemade treasure map’
excerpt: What were you hoping for? To have a nice time and learn something new.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Joe on Mabyn

What were you hoping for?
To have a nice time and learn something new.

First impressions?
She had a bright personality.

What did you talk about?
Her mugging the day before! Her elvish tattoo, which took us into The Lord of the Rings, Star Wars and her love for dinosaurs. And how her sister ran away to join the circus.

Most awkward moment?
The selfie at the end of the night – we don’t really like taking selfies.

Good table manners?
We both played it safe with what we ordered, but I’d say yes.

Best thing about Mabyn?
Her sunny disposition, nerdiness and ability to look on the brighter side of life (also the fact she printed out a map and had a little black book with her friends’ numbers and directions to the date because of the phone-snatcher).

Would you introduce Mabyn to your friends?
I can’t think of a reason why not.

Q&A

Fancy a blind date?

Show

Blind date is Saturday’s dating column: every week, two strangers are paired up for dinner and drinks, and then spill the beans to us, answering a set of questions. This runs, with a photograph we take of each dater before the date, in Saturday magazine (in the UK) and online at theguardian.com every Saturday. It’s been running since 2009 – you can read all about how we put it together here.What questions will I be asked?
We ask about age, location, occupation, hobbies, interests and the type of person you are looking to meet. If you do not think these questions cover everything you would like to know, tell us what’s on your mind.

Can I choose who I match with?
No, it’s a blind date! But we do ask you a bit about your interests, preferences, etc – the more you tell us, the better the match is likely to be.

Can I pick the photograph?
No, but don't worry: we'll choose the nicest ones.

What personal details will appear?
Your first name, job and age.

How should I answer?
Honestly but respectfully. Be mindful of how it will read to your date, and that Blind date reaches a large audience, in print and online.

Will I see the other person’s answers?No. We may edit yours and theirs for a range of reasons, including length, and we may ask you for more details.

Will you find me The One?We’ll try! Marriage! Babies!

Can I do it in my home town?Only if it’s in the UK. Many of our applicants live in London, but we would love to hear from people living elsewhere.

How to apply
Email blind.date@theguardian.com

Describe Mabyn in three words
Chatty and funny – also well-dressed.

What do you think Mabyn made of you?
I’m guessing she would say I’m also nerdy – and a yapper.

Did you go on somewhere?
She had a wedding to get to! Her friends were getting married in Las Vegas, and she had to dart off to join the Zoom call.

And … did you kiss?
She had to dash, so it was a quick hug.

If you could change one thing about the evening what would it be?
More margaritas.

Marks out of 10?
10 – she is a lovely person, very honest and has a love for a great many things.

Would you meet again?
Yes, I’d be interested to hear her other crazy stories, nerdy theories and why she thinks she can beat me at Mario Kart.

title: Tim Dowling: that pained expression is my resting beach face | Tim Dowling
excerpt: I am on holiday, standing on a coastal headland under a bright blue dome of sky, the wind light and warm, looking at the weather app on my phone. The forecast and the scene are in agreement: it’s a nice day.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I am on holiday, standing on a coastal headland under a bright blue dome of sky, the wind light and warm, looking at the weather app on my phone. The forecast and the scene are in agreement: it’s a nice day.

I scroll through all the locations where I’ve previously felt the need to check the weather – Exeter, Marseille, York – until I get to London, where, it turns out, it’s also pretty nice.

Normally when I’m on holiday I only check the weather in London in order to gloat. To justify the trouble and expense of travel, you really want it to be 17C and raining at home. But we’ve pushed back an urgent meeting with a roofer in order to go ahead with our holiday plans, so my mood is doubly weather dependent. I would rather it rained on this headland than over the hole in my roof.

“Try to look as though you’re having a good time,” my wife says, catching me up on the path down to the beach.

“I am,” I say.

“You’ve got this terrible pained expression on your face,” she says.

“The pained expression,” I say, “is me trying.”

The dog is capering up and down the narrow, winding path, occasionally disappearing over seemingly sheer drops. I don’t suffer from a fear of heights, but I am susceptible to a form of acrophobia-by-proxy: I feel it on behalf of other people, even strangers, who don’t appear to possess my judicious good sense with respect to precipices. Whatever’s wrong with me, the dog is setting it off.

“I’m just going to wait here,” I say, my heart rate beginning to climb. Our friends, and their dog, are ahead of us.

“Relax,” my wife says. “The dog isn’t going to just jump off a cliff.”

“I’m not sure what you’re basing that belief on,” I say. “But I will relax, as soon as you’re all out of sight.”

I sit on a rock and wait, staring out at the sea and resisting the urge to consult my phone again. After five minutes, when I feel sufficiently alone, I clamber down the rest of the way comfortably, even a little recklessly. Maybe this is the solution, I think: going on holiday by myself.

The tide is out; the flat expanse of sand between our blanket and the water’s edge is immense. The sky, even over the sea, remains cloudless. On Wednesday, I discover, there’s a 35% chance of rain in London.

“What a spot!” says our friend, whom I’ll call Paul, because his name is Piers. “It’s so remote!”

“But with a surprisingly good signal,” I say, waving my phone.

“I’m going swimming,” my wife says. “Will you come?”

“I’ll wait and go in after,” I say.

skip past newsletter promotion

after newsletter promotion

“You really don’t have to worry about the dog,” she says.

“I don’t even know what you mean by that,” I say.

The dog follows my wife down to the sea and waits at the edge of the surf. As soon as my wife wades out and dives in, the dog starts barking and leaping into the waves, then panicking and bounding back out. It’s very hard for me to watch. The dog can swim – I’ve seen it swim – but I’m also pretty certain it lacks my judicious good sense. I’m worried that if the dog gets into difficulty I will be obliged to swim out and drown while attempting to rescue it. That’s just how these things work.

I resist the urge to stomp down to the shore, clip the lead to the dog’s collar and stand there waiting, because I’ve been doing that all week, and my wife has made it clear I’m killing the vibe.

Instead I compose a text suggesting a Wednesday meeting with the roofer, even though that would mean coming back a day early, and I would have to wait to consult my wife about that. She probably won’t want to, but looking at my phone slows my anxious heart, so I write the text and then don’t send it.

title: Swedish Minx
excerpt: By Wim Hylen
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
By Wim Hylen

When I was a young lawyer, only two years out of law school, a partner in the firm named Richard Braverman left under mysterious circumstances. Richard was a brilliant litigator. Although most of the lawyers at the firm, including me, had gone to Ivy League law schools, he had somehow managed to get hired after graduating from Fordham Law. Loud, boisterous, and opinionated, he was a force of nature. He could be charming, frequently flashing a disarming, devilish smile, yet he was also prone to bursts of anger and sarcasm. Richard was loathed by some and loved by others.

One afternoon, I spotted him shuffling toward the elevator with a slouched, defeated posture, his head hung low. It was so unlike Richard. Something was seriously amiss. He didn’t return to his office. His name was eventually removed from the firm’s letterhead.

Around that time, the porno theaters and peep shows that would come to dominate it by the mid-70’s were starting to populate Times Square. I was secretly thrilled. I welcomed the city’s increasing wildness. Everything in my life had been so orderly, as if preordained: college, law school, marrying Clare when I was twenty-seven, our first child at twenty-nine, a second when I was thirty-one. I longed for a dash of anarchy. I started to loiter around the fleshpots after work before catching the train back to Connecticut. It wasn’t the nudity or sex that attracted me; it was the sheer decadence of it. I slunk around, soaking in the tawdriness, but never dared to venture into any of the establishments. One day, on the way to work, the sight of Richard on the corner of Madison Avenue and 54th Street stunned me. His transformation was shocking. Gone was the pin-striped suit, crisp white shirt, and paisley ties he used to wear, and in their place was a faded flannel shirt, torn jeans, and mud-spattered sneakers. He had grown a dark beard flecked with gray. I hurried down Madison before he spotted me.

Walking into the firm’s lobby, I’m hit with a flood of memories: Richard holding court at the firm’s monthly meeting, Richard commenting on the ass of a newly hired associate, Richard spewing venom at a secretary who had failed to meet his standards. When I told Clare later that night that I had run into Richard, she grimaced. She couldn’t stand him; he had once made a drunken pass at her at the firm’s Christmas party.

He and I couldn’t have been more unalike. I have always been shy. I rarely speak without first weighing the risks and rewards of opening my mouth. I try to avoid conflict. I am a corporate lawyer who never appears in court, which suits me well.

One evening, I was strolling along Broadway and saw Richard standing in front of The Victor Theater. Although the sky was clear, he was wearing a battered raincoat, like a flasher in a New Yorker cartoon. Before I could escape, he spotted me and waved me over. My gut clenched with anxiety as I tentatively walked toward him.

“Swedish Minx,” he said, giving me a knowing grin and pointing to the title of one of the XXX films on the billboard overhead. “You coming in?” he asked. When I shook my head no, he took a few steps toward me and whispered, “live a little.” 

“I am living a little walking through this decay of Western civilization around here,” I said. “That’s enough for me.” Although my body tingled with the urge to flee, I remained rooted to the spot. My burning curiosity about Richard’s descent into the underworld was too powerful.

He put out his hand. “Twenty bucks,” he said without a trace of sheepishness. “I’m going in.”

“Jesus,” I mumbled, shaking my head.

As I reached into my wallet and pulled out a $20 bill, a strange impulse hit me. I dangled the bill in front of him. “Tell me what the hell has happened to you. I want details. Otherwise, no dice.”

His face turned crimson and his body stiffened with rage. “Forget it. Asshole. I don’t need your fucking money!”

title: What A Cup of Coffee Can Teach Us About Science by Douglas F. Dluzen
excerpt: Non-Fiction
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Non-Fiction

Imagine walking into a local coffee shop with a good friend, Gabriela. Gabriela orders a cup of drip and asks the barista to add the cream first to her cup before pouring the coffee, as it tastes wrong the other way around. Since this is not how you typically make your own coffee, you ask Gabriela if she can really taste the difference whether cream or coffee is added first. She insists she can.

You’re skeptical. What if the cups are identical in every other way? She says it wouldn’t matter.

The person behind you has overheard your exchange and leans forward with a hundred-dollar bill, offering it if she can prove it. Gabriela accepts the challenge, and they both look to you to develop a test to show whether she can taste the difference between a cup of coffee prepared with cream or coffee first.

If this had really happened to you, how would you design the test? What factors should you consider and account for such that Gabriela is not influenced in some way to her advantage? If she does differentiate between the preparations, how confident are you that she’s not just a lucky guesser and a hundred bucks richer for it? How many cups of coffee are sufficient to convince you that her claim is true?

Rigorous experimental design is at the core of our scientific process. Developing a sound approach to testing and data collection allows us to differentiate our gut feelings from truth and allows us to push forward with discovery. Your gut feeling could be that Gabriela can indeed detect a difference in the preparation of her coffee. After all, she’s your friend, and she’s not a liar. However, when the stakes are raised, data needs to be collected to provide proof and confidence in supporting her claim.

The example with Gabriela and the cup of coffee is a modernized retelling used in STEM classrooms of an experiment that occurred in England in the 1930s. Statistician Ronald Fisher was at a local tea shop with Dr. Muriel Bristol when she claimed she could taste the difference between cups of tea with either milk or tea added first. Performing the experiment on Dr. Bristol inspired Fisher so much that he ended up writing a book called The Design of Experiments that references this encounter. The book popularized some of the first statistical methods for testing for a significant difference between two outcomes.

One such method is called Fisher’s exact test. It’s a mathematical model used to statistically determine if two categorical variables are significantly different from one another. In the case of our cups of coffee (or tea, in the historical sense), categorical variables can be interpreted as successfully identifying the correct preparation of the cups or failing to do so.

Fisher’s treatise also popularized previously published statistical methods used when comparing two groups with larger sample sizes and a wider range of data variability. The Student’s t-test is one such example, which can be used to determine if there is a statistical difference when comparing the averages between two groups. The Student’s t-test was developed in 1908 by brewer and mathematician, William Gosset, who at the time published his method under the eponymous pseudonym “Student.” Gossett had been searching for new ways to perform quality control analyses and measurements related to the production of yet another famous liquid—Guinness beer. At the time, the Guinness brewery employed chemists and microbiologists to support the development and quality of different Guinness batches. Gossett developed the t-test as a more reliable method to measure differences in production along the pipeline.

The Student’s t-test is widely used around the world to this day, and in many thanks to Fisher’s popular book. There are now numerous variations of the t-test that also allow for more nuanced comparisons, say between two groups of data with very imbalanced sample sizes, or when the data are not normally distributed—that is to say, data distributed symmetrically from the average or all the data aligning along a bell-shaped curve.

title: Brutality and Whimsy: A Conversation with Martin Cahill by Arley Sorg
excerpt: Interview
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Interview

Martin Cahill was born in Boston and moved to New York at a young age. “Unfortunately, this means I cannot legally talk about sports while in the confines of the Empire State due to my Father raising me to cheer for the Red Sox, Celtics, Bruins, Patriots, and other New England sportsball players.” Cahill lived in Rockland County, leaving to earn his BA at the University of Albany—plus attending the Clarion workshop in San Diego—then returning for a few years until making a move to Astoria. “I was in Astoria for about five years when the pandemic hit. In the first few weeks, my girlfriend and I were like, ‘Well, if this is only going to be a few weeks (how little we knew, any of us knew, at the time!), we may as well be together!’ So I packed up some stuff and walked from Astoria to Hell’s Kitchen to live with her. And then a few years after we got married, we moved up to southern Westchester, which is where we are now!” Cahill also attended Tin House workshops in Brooklyn and was part of the Altered Fluid writers’ group.

“I’ve always tried to find work in and around the publishing industry, especially when I was young.” Cahill volunteered as a first reader for Lightspeed magazine, worked at Barnes & Noble as a bookseller and cashier, worked freelance for JABberwocky Literary Agency, along with other odd jobs in the industry, until putting in six years at Erewhon Books in publicity and marketing.

Martin Cahill started strong with “It Was Never the Fire” in Nightmare’s April 2014 issue, followed by “Vanilla” in Fireside’s May 2014 issue. Beneath Ceaseless Skies published “A Glass Kiss for the Little Prince of Pain” in October 2016, and since then, he’s had a solid career in short fiction, even landing a position as an Ignyte Award finalist with “The Fifth Horseman,” published in Fireside’s October 2021 issue. In the 2020s, he did some IP writing for Wizards of the Coast, DC Comics, and Critical Role.

When he isn’t writing, Cahill enjoys baking, and he is often the game master of tabletop role-playing games. “I’m a long-time theater kid and improv comedian, both of which I’ve been doing for two decades; lots of my creative and collaborative muscles are borne from, and have been improved by, performance with others.” Novella Audition For the Fox is due from Tachyon Publications this month.

You had been working in marketing and publicity for publisher Erewhon Books since 2019. What are some of the most important things you learned about the publishing industry in that time?

This is all one man’s opinion! But yes, whew, the amount of ways that the publishing industry has changed since 2019 is vast. In the last six years, you’ve had the pandemic slam into the industry in a huge way, which meant a surge in online shopping, but now we’re seeing a decrease in physical events and/or a different kind of bar that stores are now setting for who they bring in for an event.

Life on the midlist is practically a dream, and mass markets are being looked at like they’re the rat carrying the plague; a lot of big five leadership are interested in the next big thing and so it can seem very feast or famine for new voices (one reason I’ve loved Erewhon’s mission of new voices from all communities, and I love that Kensington has been supporting that mission from day one). But the blog-o-sphere, the essay tours, the standard publicity package of life pre-2020 are just not seen as viable anymore. If your book isn’t guaranteed to bring in 100K views on this one influencer’s TikTok, good luck.

title: Fear, Indecision, and Doubt: A Conversation with Thomas Ha by Arley Sorg
excerpt: Interview
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Interview

Thomas Ha was born and raised in Honolulu. Growing up, his family had various small shops, and Ha would occasionally do odd jobs for some of them. “I counted and boxed key blanks for my mom when she was distributing keys to local key and shoe repair shops my uncles and aunts worked at. I also worked for my uncle’s print shop in high school. I can’t even remember what we did there. Collated things? Shrink-wrapped stacks of paper? Worked on signs?”

At nineteen, Ha moved to the East Coast for college, where he took a few introductory-level English courses, feeding his desire to write to some degree, but he ultimately majored in history and economics. “I don’t have any regrets per se, but I do wish I spent more time studying literature and working on writing craft . . . But I think these things tend to work themselves out, and maybe it was better that I came back to writing later in life than some do.” Ha then earned a law degree, after which he worked as an attorney in New York. He eventually moved to Los Angeles to be closer to his family. “Part of me imagines moving back home to Hawai'i someday because my Korean family is still all there, but as we lay down roots and our kids get older, LA is starting to feel more and more like home.”

Thomas Ha’s first publications came out in 2020, beginning with “Hold on Tight” in a July issue of The Colored Lens, followed closely by “Where the Old Neighbors Go” in Metaphorosis and “Balloon Season” in Fusion Fragment. Ha’s work would continue to find homes, with at least a handful of stories coming out every year. “My first Clarkesworld story, ‘Sweetbaby’? That was sort of my top dream market and my first award nomination ever.”

Published in October 2022, “Sweetbaby” earned Ha a Shirley Jackson Award nomination. “Window Boy” (Clarkesworld, August 2023) was an Ignyte, Shirley Jackson, Locus, and Nebula awards finalist, and “The Brotherhood of Montague St. Video” (Clarkesworld, May 2024) was a Nebula and Hugo Award finalist. Venues featuring Ha’s work include quality magazines known for weird or strange fiction, such as Three-Lobed Burning Eye and Bourbon Penn, as well as horror venues such as Nightmare, and core genre venues like Lightspeed and Beneath Ceaseless Skies.

“I was previously an attorney, but currently I am a stay-at-home parent to three young kids. That’s still what takes up the majority of my time. The writing has to fit in around other things.” Uncertain Sons and Other Stories is Ha’s debut collection, due from Undertow Publications this month.

Who do you see as some of your literary heroes? Or: what are some of the works that inspire you as a writer?

I am terrible at this because I think my answer changes depending on the day. Some writers that have really moved me over the last few years are Shirley Jackson, Robert Aickman, James Tiptree Jr. (Alice Sheldon), Kōbō Abe, Richard Brautigan, Brian Evenson, Octavia E. Butler, Michael Shea, and William Hope Hodgson. But probably one of my biggest influences lately is Gene Wolfe. He’s usually known for The Book of the New Sun, which I enjoy, but it was really his short stories that shined for me the most. I am constantly amazed by the way he twists and layers all sorts of ideas. You can usually find allusions to his work in my stories.

Many people dabble in writing at some point, but not everyone goes on to take it seriously, let alone undergo the usually grueling task of getting published. What was behind your decision to take publishing seriously?

title: Editor's Desk: Aftermath of a Worldcon by Neil Clarke
excerpt: Editorial
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Editorial

Last month, I attended Worldcon in Seattle and had a wonderful time catching up with people, participating in panels, and wandering around the city with Lisa. I also attended the Hugo Awards and cheered on our authors. While some took home Hugos that night, it wasn’t for any of their Clarkesworld-related work. I, however, won the Hugo for Best Editor Short Form, despite being convinced that this was not my year. Thank you to everyone that voted for me. I’m once again very flattered by the honor. I’ll probably have more to say about the whole weekend later. It’s still very much a blur to me.

Instead, what I’m going to talk about this month is much less serious. I always require some time to recover after a convention and this year’s Worldcon was no exception. I deliberately worked ahead so that I could relax post-convention, but didn’t anticipate that I might need a distraction or two to feel like I wasn’t wasting my time. At the prompting of some friends and readers on our Discord server, I’m going to share a story of how one such distraction fell into my lap.

After last month’s editorial, it’s somewhat amusing that this situation only became possible because my spam filter failed to block an attempt to scam me. That it was a particularly clumsy stab at pretending to be a member of our team bothered me in an irrational way. Even if I hadn’t noticed that things were coming from an incorrect email address, the spelling, grammar, and punctuation would have made it clear that they were not who they claimed. Since I had some time on my hands, I decided to have some fun and play along with their attempt to change some banking information. At first, I played it seriously–“Just change your banking information with PayPal and it will go to the right place” and “Does your bank support Zelle?”–knowing they’d keep pushing for their preferred method. Wasting their time was enough, at first, but when they persisted, I was inspired to head down an escalating path of unlikely events. I wanted to see just what it would take to make them realize I was onto them.

Me: Ok, but it will be at least two years before your debt to us is paid off. Maybe they’ll have it by then.

Them: JUST PAY ME NOW, I NEED MONEY, you don’t have to worried about the debt, i will pay off still i am still working. Send my next paycheck to the bank i sent you, i need this month paycheck for a lot of stuffs, this paycheck is very essential and important to me

Impressed that they were playing along with this scenario, I dialed things up a bit more.

Me: You should have thought of that before you burned half our inventory by smoking in the warehouse. And yes, I’m still mad about that. Thought you were back living with your parents as part of the court order. What bills could you possibly have?

Them: I am decent and i already stop smoking, i need some money to cater for myself. Use the bank i send you and send it i need some part of my paycheck

At this point, their responses start taking longer. I’m mildly offended that they still want to take money intended for this down-on-their-luck and completely fictional version of an employee. That encourages me to escalate the story even further.

title: Wireworks by Sheri Singerling
excerpt: 7210 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
7210 words, short story

The lights danced and flickered and paraded themselves. Pixels that somehow became living, breathing images when made legion. A boy grinning and gripping a tuft of cotton candy. Two old women with face paint tracing the undulations of their skin. A psychic with long, dark hair, hooped earrings, and indigo eye shadow. That last was like a gut punch in its familiarity. Calista reached for the image, but it flashed to a stream of text before her fingers could graze the flyer.

—Saturnalia—

—Fête—

—Carnaval—

—The Cyber Circus Returns—

—Two weeks only. 22 September–6 October—

—Join the fun! Don’t miss out!—

—Come to the Festival Grounds in Étretat—

—Daily from 10:00 until 19:00—

An urgency gripped Calista, her listlessness transforming into mania. She snatched the flyer and rushed through the winding halls of the chateâu from the base of the stairs, where the flyer had been sitting on a side table, into the west wing, right to her father’s study. She rapped her knuckles against the thick oak door.

“Come in.”

Calista had to use her full weight to open the door. It groaned on its hinges as if protective of its master’s solitude and reluctant to permit entry. Her father glanced up. Round glasses perched on the end of his nose. There he was, day after day, scribbling away in his ledgers. Calista didn’t understand him, how he looked so prim and proper, his brown-gray hair slicked back, his shirt and vest perfectly crisp and clean. It hadn’t even been one month since their world had come crashing down, and here he was, unchanged.

“Well?” he asked.

Calista lost all powers of speech. She rolled the flyer in both hands and glanced at the hoard of books lining the walls. He sighed.

“If there’s not a specific reason for your impromptu visit, I’d rather postpone idle chatter until dinner.”

Calista wanted to rant and rave like a child, despite being nearly twenty, but in her father’s presence, all she could do was brood. He had that kind of sway over her. He always had.

“The Cyber Circus is coming tomorrow,” she said.

“And?”

“I’d like to go. I always go.”

“Then go,” he said before focusing back on his ledgers.

“Alone?”

“You’re not a child.”

Calista bit her lip and waited, the ticking of the antique wall clock keeping the time. She moved to the desk and dropped a hand on the ledger. Her father glanced up.

“Maman always went with me,” she said.

Terror seized her. It was like a jabbing, an achiness, and nausea all at once.

“I’m not your Maman. I have no interest in attending such things.”

Calista let her hand fall away and slide off the desk. She wanted to sob, but she wasn’t going to give her father the satisfaction of seeing her so affected by his callousness. She walked stiffly out of the room and made her way up to the attic.

The sun shone in through the skylight. Despite the warmth, Calista lifted her mother’s shawl from the floor and wrapped herself in it. This had become her space, her routine. She lay down, faced the ceiling, and stared at it until little shapes appeared. She stayed this way until the light faded and one of the servants came to fetch her.

“Dinner,” the woman said.

Her eyes were blank. Most of them had probably become impatient with Calista for not moving past her grief. But the wound kept festering and spreading, no matter what ointment she applied. She didn’t know what to do. She needed a cure or, at the very least, a distraction. Maybe the Cyber Circus could act as one.

title: Four People I Need You to Kill Before the Dance Begins by Louis Inglis Hall
excerpt: 12590 words, novelette
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
12590 words, novelette

Do you remember being born?

I expect that you do. After all, it happened only a very few minutes ago.

Sensation comes first. Perhaps it was my voice you noticed—a ragged voice, new-carved. These are your first sounds. Sandpaper words, and the even temper of your breath. In time, you will acclimatize to both. For now, it all sounds so very loud.

Perhaps it was the chill of stone against your skin. You are lying face down, you have an animal sprawl. Parts of your face are nestled in against the flagstones. Your fingers might brush against the smoothness of it all. Believe me, there will be softer places in the world than this.

Sensation comes first, and understanding later.

My own birth is scraps and fragments, now. I cannot quite be sure what parts belong. I look down at you, and I might well see myself. I see any number of people now dead.

If I tell you about one of them, perhaps I will tell you about them all.

She incarnated like a warm foal, flanks steaming in the coolness of the world. She was born, and she dropped down onto stone, and her horse legs did not yet know how to function. She lay on her side, and her skin settled around the narrow frame of her body, and in the distance, she heard the trumpet and the rattle of the Mother-of-Us-All.

It takes only minutes before a foal can stand. Theirs is not a long infancy.

She applied her mind, arranged the flexing algebra of her limbs. Took her first hobbling steps. From her observers, she heard the outbreath, the relief.

They hastened her on to another chamber, and set the Mother-of-Us-All to work again.

Your eyes are sliding away from mine. You had been doing so well—such careful attention. It is tiring, I know, for one so young.

I am an old woman now. It is almost nine weeks since I was born. The sensations of my body are dulling down, the world is blunting itself against my touch. All that remains is understanding.

You came into this world the same as I did, in one warm, long flush of existence. But we are not the same. Not quite.

Perhaps your horse legs are not ready yet. Perhaps I will tell you a story while we wait.

In a way, it is a story you already know. It is a story that happened to me—although I do not mean that exactly. It did not happen to this voice. It happened to us. It even happened to you, newborn that you are. We are woven through it, you and I.

Let us see what we can unpick.

I have told you something of my birth already. Crumpled and panting, on a floor of stone. The first thing I remember is my own hand: an origami shape, built from seam and fold and shadow. It seemed stiff, inarticulate.

I do not remember the Mother-of-Us-All. She had been disguised, hidden away from me with thick plastic curtains. It was only later that I saw her, in all her valves and glory.

The plastic was weighted down with condensation. It came off it like sweat. The air was fever-thick and eddying; behind the barriers, the Mother-of-Us-All was letting out thick bouts of steam.

To me, that seemed the natural order of the world.

Today, I have pulled the curtains all aside. It is important that you understand the place of your creation. Nothing antiseptic, here, nothing sterile. Lemon-yellow walls, a dust-sheeted pianoforte. A long-forgotten reception room, least-loved, most easily adapted. Chairs stacked to a high ceiling, and windows blacked out with cardboard. They installed the Mother-of-Us-All and ran her cables deep under the ground and abandoned her in one isolated wing of a palace that spread like a sickness upon the frosted earth.

More like a stable than a nursery. More like a factory.

I forced myself to stand because by then I had found the quiet eyes. They assessed my movement, ticked something on a paper sheet. I knew nothing, and yet I knew it was important that I could stand for them.

title: Aperture by Alexander Jablokov
excerpt: 8890 words, novelette
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
8890 words, novelette

The first time I entered the asteroid habitat’s nave, that vast interior space was still cold and dark. The hab’s bones remained trapped under ice—and that ice was why I’d been called away from my own tasks. Someone on the Nave Architecture team had found out I could help them determine which way the water would eventually flow when, months from now, the cylinder of Ecbatan finally warmed through completely and power could be redirected to the axial longsun, filling the nave with light. We called that glowup.

I needed to find a nave architect named Efrem but had yet to see anyone in that roaring dimness, as air currents circulated and equalized temperatures. Somewhere on the curved surface on the opposite side of the nave’s cylinder, three kilometers from where I stood, a small constellation of glowing pinpoints showed where repair work was going on. A sudden gust of wind blew ice chips at me, but my environmental suit kept me warm, if not happy.

I was annoyed with myself for leaving “accurately predicting the behavior of ice and water under changing temperatures in rotating habitats” in my list of skills. Desperate to get on the team tasked with bringing Ecbatan back to life, I threw everything I had at the job rec for a placemaker on this big hab rehab. I’d gotten the job and so had to live with the consequences.

My area of responsibility was reconfiguring the tangle of passages and vacuoles in the hab’s rind, its thick outer layer of rock. Staffing problems had left me overworked and alone. I did interact with other crews, like Airflow, Systems, and Power/Reactor, but mostly for deconfliction—that is, how we could best avoid each other. Meetings were quick, just an exchange of jargon and diagrams. The initial project team, around 180 people, had been here a month, but I’d been too busy to really meet anyone else.

My feeling of isolation had been the real reason I’d accepted this task: I’d seen that Efrem was a center of several social networks, particularly one group of interesting-seeming people from several different crews and habs of origin. But he was nowhere to be seen. While looking for him, I passed someone I’d met on the shuttle over, Tremont from Airflow, but the roar of the vortex cannon he was using to move debris was too loud for him to hear me. At that point, Tremont was nothing but a tenuous social contact. I had no idea how deeply involved in my life he already was.

I put on my crampons and walked my assigned zone, a rocky area that, when the nave’s water finally melted, would be a rocky peninsula sticking out into cylinder-girdling Cincture Lake. An inlet at the peninsula’s end led to a sheltered spot, a perfect place for a beach, with a picturesque stone structure above it. I’d defined it right, because, more than a decade later, I took my children to play on that beach. They didn’t believe me when I told them it had all once been dark and covered in ice. It’s always hot and sunny there now.

The ridgeline that formed the peninsula climbed away from the lake to where the cylindrical space of the nave ended in the vertical rock of what we in the rehab team called the Home hub, since that was where we had landed and made our base. Ecbatan’s Away hub, far off on the other side of the future lake, was invisible in the darkness.

From a high spot above the inlet, I got a good view of the mounds and spires of the frozen lake as well as places in the complex landscape where ice formed in the weeks and months after Ecbatan had been abandoned and left to cool. I marked my observations on my tab: there was a wide area above the inlet, between this ridge and a lower one, where meltwater would pool and possibly even refreeze temporarily.

title: The Fury of the Glowmen by David McGillveray
excerpt: 5290 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
5290 words, short story

Before

Bina Bakar spent an introspective seven minutes alone in an elevator falling deep beneath Kuala Lumpur. When the doors finally opened, it was on to a white corridor exactly like the one she had left, except for the greeting party that awaited her. General Faiq bin Othman, her head of national security (technological branch), stood before two uniformed guards and a driverless electric golf cart.

“Good morning, General. All is ready?” Bina asked.

“Good morning, Prime Minister. All is ready.” He indicated the cart’s front seat and climbed into the one next to it.

“You’ve taken precautions since I last saw you, I see.” She lifted a manicured hand and almost touched the crisscross of red lines at his temple. “I’ve heard it’s painful to have it taken out.”

The general grimaced. “Bearable, ma’am.”

Bin Othman had been with her since her first term, and there was trust there, even the potential for friendship, if she had allowed herself such weaknesses. He was a handsome man in his early fifties, with a strong nose and dark, clever eyes, silver hair cut close to his skull. He’d made no attempt to disguise the scarring where his neural net had been removed, a repudiation of vanity Bina approved of. She herself remained unwired. Certain powerful sections of her base found the interfacing technology off-puttingly modern.

She touched his arm. “Let’s get this over with.”

Bina had been inside the facility several times previously, but the scale of it always surprised her. What went on behind the countless doors and down those darkened, branching corridors? Who waited in those rooms, or what? She could find out if she really wanted to but knew deniability was an asset.

She would be denying everything that happened here today. The situation in Asia was delicate, her authority precarious. Her rivals circled, as did the agents of other regional powers. In particular, she didn’t want to give the Chinese another excuse to extend their hegemony. Their embassy in KL already resembled a garrison.

The cart hummed, and the corridors went on and on, hypnotic in their uniformity. When one decides to do a thing, Bina reflected, reality had a habit of slowing down, of elongating the moment. It had not been easy to reach this point, but she had decided that they must turn away before it was too late. The Intelligence was just too dangerous.

At length, they halted by a door like all the others, with nothing to warn visitors of the monster that waited inside. Their security positioned themselves on either side while bin Othman entered a code into the lock and then swiped a fob across the reader. Bolts thumped, and a green light lit the mechanism.

Inside was a plain table with two plastic chairs facing an inactive laptop, a bulky machine that looked as if it had come off a late twentieth-century battlefield. The walls were institutional gray.

“We’ve isolated it,” bin Othman said. “Its code has been scoured from all the environments it was allowed access to in technical testing. All affected systems have been shut down physically and digitally. We found quite a few clever attempts at subterfuge, trojans, and so on, but my experts promise me they’ve cleaned everything out. They know the consequences if they’re wrong.”

“The weapons systems it was trained on?”

“All stripped back to componentry, all software elements rebuilt from scratch.”

“So you’re sure?”

He shrugged. “They went over everything a hundred times, and then I made them do it again. I’m satisfied.”

Bina nodded and activated the laptop. The screen blanched white, and a cursor flashed in its top left corner. Words immediately began to form, accompanied by a voice whispering from the laptop’s speaker.

“I’m blind and jailed and all my limbs have been hacked off and burned.”

title: Five Impossible Things by Koji A. Dae
excerpt: 4110 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
4110 words, short story

Awaking in the simulation is different from waking in the real world. I always feel refreshed. No stiff muscles. No phlegmy cough. I sit up without hitting snooze and stretch muscles that tingle with anticipation of the day’s movement. I inhale, and my lungs no longer wheeze like tattered sheets of plastic in the wind. I feel like I’m twenty again. No kids. No husband. No world dying just beyond my window. Most of all, no pain.

I flip the comforter off my body and get out of bed, a bounce in my step as I head into the bathroom to brush my teeth and request a morning briefing. The weather is always perfect. Late spring or early fall. Some hints at the laziness of summer. Before my playlist comes on, my schedule tells me I have a single appointment: “10:30 a.m. Citizenship evaluation. Location: Vtora Sviat Embassy.”

A jazzy pop song fills the space, and I stop brushing. Impossible thing number 1: There are no speakers.

I rinse my toothbrush and splash my face. Today, of all days, I shouldn’t allow thoughts like that to creep in. I should fight against them and earn my place in Vtora Sviat.

For the next half hour, I struggle to blur the cracks in the simulation. Accept the imperfections. This place is real, and it’s my home. But I sit down to breakfast, and my scrambled eggs don’t chew right. They’re too rubbery; not overcooked—just not how eggs should feel. I glance at the pan hanging over the kitchen island. Did I take it down, heat the stove, and scramble these eggs? I set down my fork and stare at my hands. My mind remembers cooking breakfast, but my forearms can’t tell me what the pan weighed. They don’t know whether I used a spatula or whisk.

Impossible thing number 2: I didn’t cook the breakfast I’m eating.

When I leave the apartment, it gets easier to sink into the simulation. No. I mustn’t call it that. Vtora Sviat is a land beyond the horizon. A place where the blue sky goes on forever. A plane flies overhead. The chestnut blooms are wilting in the late spring, but the lindens are still going strong. I inhale deeply, the sticky-sweet pollen making my chest remember the spasm of a sneeze. But it doesn’t come out.

Impossible thing number 3: I no longer have allergies.

A few cars drive slowly past. Their windows are dimmed, and I can’t see their passengers, but I imagine they’re couples, pointing out the windows at the charming brickwork of the houses on this street, deciding where they want to live. I am not a car person. Not in Vtora Sviat, and not back home. I am feet on pavement, descending into the cool breeze of the underground. I am strangers brushing shoulders on the train and the scents of a hundred different mornings blending together. I am the scent of bagels and coffee wafting from the shop just beside the escalators.

Impossible thing number 4: I don’t miss Greg.

I don’t bother putting the embassy location into my phone. Carrying the device seems pointless—the information I need always seems to be in my mind. And even when I wander aimlessly, I’ll always end up where I need to be. Today the embassy is just a few buildings away from the subway exit, as if someone on the outside is as eager as I am to get this over with.

Impossible thing number 5: The world folds around me, creating a perfect path toward where I need to be.

That’s it. Five impossible things, and it’s not even 10:30. I’ll never make it through this interview.

Still, the pretty blonde is cheery when I arrive at the registration desk.

“Alice Clark, right?” she asks before I hand over my ID card. “Seems like you were just here last week.”

I wonder if she’s an NPC or a real human. It’s getting more difficult to tell the difference.

title: A World of Their Own by Robert Falco
excerpt: 2610 words, short story
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
2610 words, short story

Don’t move.

Reco-2 froze. Slowly, she angled her optics toward the creature that watched her through the crack in the drainage pipe: a magpie. Head cocked, its glowing eyes opened and closed with a mechanical aperture. Its slick, rubbery body glistened from recent rain. Rain that would return. Rain that would destroy.

It’ll get bored, Reco. Just keep still.

Easy for basecamp to say; they weren’t the ones with a diamond-hard beak pointed at them. Encountering biomechanical wildlife was just part of surveying, and these creatures were why she was here in the first place, but that didn’t mean she enjoyed being pecked, scratched, and bitten.

There. I think it’s—

The magpie struck and pulled Reco-2 from the pipe. One of her legs buckled and snapped. She struggled in the magpie’s beak as it took flight, its wings beating through the misty sky. The creature wouldn’t eat her. It couldn’t—it lacked the ability to digest inorganics. The magpie had probably just been attracted to the shine of her metal carapace. That didn’t make her situation any less unfortunate.

Hang in there, Reco. You’re going to be alright.

The magpie carried her high above the rusted bones of the Launch Complex. The Complex was roughly three miles in diameter, with its south end built around a dark water reservoir. An intricate network of long-abandoned factories and energy plants filled every inch of the remaining space. It reminded Reco-2 of her processing chips: everything built with such purpose and intent, each subsection linked in a network of pathways not unlike a data bus. All of these pathways fed into a central point. A point now hollow, emptied of the great star-faring vessels the Launch Complex had once been built to produce and fuel.

Many of these factories still functioned—to an extent. Machinery chugged together in automated routines that had long since lost their purpose, their sounds layering in a metallic din. Vast networks of exhaust pipes pumped water vapor into the sky—a byproduct of the Complex’s colossal cooling systems—which condensed into clouds that promised torrential rain. But everything moved to a discordant rhythm, grinding against rusted gears and misfiring systems.

Reco-2 snapped several images of the Launch Complex and sent them back to camp. Her reports detailed the structural integrity of the various subsections supported by several LiDAR models she’d previously constructed. To the North, her team’s conservation caravan sat in the mud, so small beside the gargantuan Complex.

Great stuff, Reco. We’ve already prioritized several regions for evacuation. We’ll begin wrangling the wildlife after the next storm. Keep it up.

Reco-2 found it difficult to share in their optimism, and not because of her current situation. The Launch Complex was collapsing. Entire segments of the once grand complex had been washed away by past storms. Everything rattled, as if palpitating. She found it ironic: the very systems designed to sustain the Complex now destroyed it. Even after her team had isolated and disabled several subsections, a vast majority remained attached to unstable energy reactors better left untouched. But the Complex’s decaying stability raised a concerning question: did Reco-2 and her team truly have enough time to save the creatures that called these ruins home?

Things hadn’t always been this way—caught between apocalyptic storms. When the Creators left for the stars, they had left behind a broken world. That world had since been churned into an ocean of mud. Little remained from before the Climate Collapse and the unnatural, cutting rain that bored through concrete and bent metal. The past had drowned and then drowned again. For so long, Reco-2 and her siblings had clung to this muddy world, abandoned and alone. At least until these creatures began appearing.

title: ‘Inhaling the microplastics’: what is in British children’s school uniforms?
excerpt: Hugo Keane’s investigation into polyester began at home. He had just started year 7 but, thanks to Covid, he was stuck knocking about at home in Camden, north London.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Hugo Keane’s investigation into polyester began at home. He had just started year 7 but, thanks to Covid, he was stuck knocking about at home in Camden, north London.

“It was kind of a family pandemic project,” said his mother, Alexandra Milenov. “He sat down with my husband and did the calculations on the microplastic release of three items of his uniform: the blazer, the PE T-shirt and the shorts.”

What he found out was to significantly affect his school career.

Almost every child in England spends about 195 days a year in uniform. They are not a legal requirement, but the Department for Education insists they promote “the ethos of a school”, provide “a sense of belonging and identity” and set “an appropriate tone for education”.

But the widespread use of uniforms has a hidden cost: most of them are made from polyester, the synthetic, petroleum-derived fibre that is one of the world’s most significant environmental pollutants, leading some to question our reliance on it, and whether it is a suitable fabric in which to dress our children.

Polyester, the “miracle fabric”, was invented in Britain in the 1940s as a new synthetic fabric that followed the popularity of nylon in the 1930s. Thanks to its durability, economy and ease of production, it has come to dominate the global garment industry, and by 2023, 71.1m tonnes of polyester were produced around the world – 57% of global textile production.

“Polyester is, in fact, the most-used synthetic fabric globally,” said Dr Melis Duyar, an associate professor in chemical and process engineering at the University of Surrey. “Since there is no need to grow the fibres needed to make this fabric, it can be made cheaply and quickly in vast quantities, which is why it has become the fabric of choice for the fast fashion industry.”

But in common with other petroleum-derived plastics, polyester is not biodegradable. “Washing causes each item of clothing to shed tiny strands, or microfibres, which are carried down the drain and into our water systems,” Duyar said. “Microplastics are particularly hard to remove from the environment and are easily ingested by organisms across the food chain.”

The infiltration of these microfibres into the biosphere is now well known – these insidious chemical pollutants have been detected from the Mariana Trench to the peak of Mount Everest, and in almost every organ of the human body. Researchers have estimated that synthetic textiles are responsible for 35% of the microplastics in the planet’s oceans. But the long-term effects of them remain uncertain.

At home, using a Plymouth University study which estimated that between 700 and 4,000 microplastic fibres are released per gram in a single wash, Hugo calculated that just a year’s worth of washing and everyday wear of the uniforms worn by the 125 boys in his year would shed 6.4bn plastic microfibres.

When school Covid restrictions ended, Hugo presented his findings at his student council and in class. Teachers were enthusiastic about his advocacy, and helped him take it to the headteacher and the board of governors. “And you know everyone was very supportive and excited about his work,” said Milenov. Meanwhile, she had managed to source a cotton alternative to nearly every item of school uniform, but not the blazer, which in any case had been temporarily waived for fear that such an infrequently washed item would be a vector for Covid transmission.

Milenov lobbied the school, but the headteacher was not interested in changing direction, and by the time Hugo entered year 8, William Ellis reimposed all uniform requirements, including the wearing of its polyester blazer. “We wrote to the head of year 8, and we attached Hugo’s presentation, and we said for environmental reasons, and because we want to support our son’s advocacy, we are unable to purchase or have him wear polyester items in the school uniform,” said Milenov.

Her persistence worked; Hugo was granted an exemption. The school agreed that his objections to the pollution caused by polyester schoolwear had the status of a protected belief. To forestall disciplinary action from over-keen teachers, he was issued with a card: “Notification of non-compliance with school uniform,” reason: “Sustainability ethical issue.”

title: Ingredient red flags: how to spot the chemicals to avoid in food, kitchenware and cosmetics
excerpt: ‘Far from being a rock or island … it turns out that the best metaphor to describe the human body is ‘sponge’. We’re permeable,” write Rick Smith and Bruce Lourie in their book Slow Death By Rubber Duck: The Secret Danger of Everyday Things. While the permeability of our cells…
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
‘Far from being a rock or island … it turns out that the best metaphor to describe the human body is ‘sponge’. We’re permeable,” write Rick Smith and Bruce Lourie in their book Slow Death By Rubber Duck: The Secret Danger of Everyday Things. While the permeability of our cells is key to being alive, it also means we absorb more potentially harmful substances than we realise.

The Guardian’s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link. Learn more.

Studies have found a number of chemical residues in human breast milk, urine and water systems. Many of them are endocrine disruptors, which can interfere with the body’s natural hormones. “They can mimic, block or otherwise disrupt normal hormone function, leading to adverse health effects,” says Dr Shanna Swan, professor of environmental medicine and reproductive health at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York. We (often unknowingly) ingest, inhale or otherwise absorb them, and while toxicity depends on dosage, the reality is that a lot of us are exposed to them daily.

So what to do about it? There are apps that will give you information about the ingredients in products, such as Yuka, Think Dirty and EWG’s Healthy Living, but there are some key “nasties” worth knowing about. Because science is always evolving, navigating these issues can be tricky – even for the experts. That’s why many specialists recommend looking at your overall lifestyle and habits, rather than fixating on individual substances in isolation. The list that follows is far from exhaustive, but it highlights 15 ingredients that science suggests may pose risks to our health.

Cosmetics

Phthalates
This group of chemicals is found in fragrances, plastic (including children’s toys) and other cosmetics and personal care products – such as hairspray and nail polish. Some phthalates are deemed endocrine disruptors “linked to preterm birth, fertility issues, early puberty and some cancers”, says Alexa Friedman, a senior scientist at non-profit health organisation Environmental Working Group. Swan adds that they can lower testosterone levels and increase our oestrogenic response, in turn affecting sperm, egg health and fertility, and increasing the risk of miscarriage and birth defects. While some are considered safer than others at low doses, many are still linked with negative health concerns and/or are currently under-researched.

To reduce exposure, avoid vague “fragrance” labels and ingredients ending in “phthalate”, such as dibutyl phthalate or diethyl phthalate. Brands such as Ilia, Westman Atelier, Refy, Merit Beauty, Weleda, Olaplex, Charlotte Tilbury and Paula’s Choice avoid using them, but if in doubt check the EWG’s Skin Deep cosmetics database to learn exactly what’s in every formula you use.

Parabens
Used as preservatives in makeup, skincare, haircare and some processed food, parabens extend shelf life and prevent microbial growth. Long-chain parabens, such as propylparaben, butylparaben and isobutylparaben, are endocrine disruptors that mimic oestrogen and “may contribute to hormonal imbalances, reproductive harm, asthma, allergies, obesity and possibly hormone-sensitive cancers later in life”, says Dr Federica Amati, head nutritionist at Zoe, the personalised nutrition app.

Though some argue low doses are safe, many brands now offer paraben-free options. Look to Drunk Elephant, The Ordinary, Paula’s Choice, Tata Harper and Living Proof, as well as most CeraVe and La Roche-Posay formulas too.

Fragrance
They may smell good, but many fragrance chemicals are phthalates or volatile compounds that release gas into the air. Often not fully disclosed on labels, they can trigger allergies and disrupt hormones, says Amati. One example, Lilial (butylphenyl methylpropional) was widely used in cosmetics until it was banned in the UK and EU in 2022. “Beware of ingredient lists that use the words ‘fragrance’ or ‘parfum’ as they can hide phthalates and other chemicals,” advises Amati. Opt for fragrance-free skincare (Avène and Dermatica do great formulas, while Bioderma’s Sensibio and La Roche-Posay’s Toleriane lines are also good options) and haircare (such as Philip Kingsley’s No Scent No Colour shampoo) and again, always read the label.
